title: WB Multi-Partner Fund Somalia 2018-2021
description:
Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19
This intervention builds on current ongoing Sida support to the World Bank Multi-Partner Fund for Somalia (2014-2018), decision number 2014-003041. The current Sida support to the WB-MPF focus on four areas:
1. Enabling economic growth
2. Effective and accountable government
3. Urban infrastructure
4. Analytical and technical assistance.

In September 2018, the World Bank Board of Directors approved a new four-year strategy for Somalia 2019-2022. This strategy is the first World Bank strategy for Somalia in 30 years and signals a renewed confidence and trust by the World Bank in Somalia´s road map to development. This Country Partnership Framework (CPF) is currently funded by 10 donors through the the Multi-Partner Fund modality for delivery. Sweden is the fourth biggest contributor to the fund. The MPF modality is per definition a pooled fund mechanism with is the preferred mechanism of financing in conflict and post-conflict contexts. The MPF is one of three pooled funding mechanisms in Somalia established as part of the Somalia Development and Reconstruction Facility. The MPF is administered by the World Bank and operates in close cooperation with the federal government of Somalia and the contributing donors. WB-MPF are well aligned with government priorities, as articulated in the National Development Plan (2017-2019) and together cover all eight pillars of the NDP. Hence, national ownership and alignment to principles of development effectiveness is adhered to. As Administrator of the Trust Fund, the World Bank is responsible for ensuring that the MPF and its funds are used in accordance with the administrative agreements and that recipients use MPF funds in accordance with the grant agreements.

The MPF has a specific focus support to core state functions, socioeconomic recovery and sustainable development compared with the UN Fund being more broad in scope and the AfDB focusing on rehabilitation and development of infrastructure. Sida has provided support to UN-MPTF since 2015 (decision number 2015-002435 and 2018-001376). The AFDB-SIF is currently the only funding window which Sida does not contribute. The AFDB-SIF has only started in 2017.

The overall aim of the CPF 2019-2022 is to lay foundations for the longer-term poverty reduction and inclusive growth by focusing on priority areas and constraints creating the current Somalia "dual development trap" created by low level of trusts and exacerbated by widespread vulnerability of repeated shocks. The strategy has two focus areas (1) Strengthening Institutions to Deliver Services and (2) Restoring Economic Resilience and Opportunities. The first focus area will strengthen ongoing governance programs with a new focus on fiscal space and improving access to - and quality of - key social services and resilience. Programs will specifically target public finance management reforms, domestic revenue mobilization and resource sharing, basic delivery systems for social services; and urban resilience. The second focus area aims to increase economic resilience as a basis for long-run poverty reduction and inclusive growth by improving business environment and lowering barriers to market entry, increasing access to finance for inclusion and digital development; and improved access to water and renewable energy. 

Although the new World Bank strategy covers the period 2019-2022, Sida proposal for support is during 2019-2020, with a total amount of 200 million SEK as well as a support to current MPF programs of 75 million SEK in 2018. Depending if and when the World Bank manage to secure additional IDA financing and if the World Bank manages to re-adjust current plans for the health sector in line with Sida recommendations, Sida will consider contributing additional funds to the MPF during 2021-2022.

To regulate Sida’s commitment and conditions for supporting the Somalia MPF, Sida and the World Bank will use the 2016 template agreed in December 2016 by Consultative Group on Operational Principles for Trust Funds and Partnership (CGOP) “Model Form of Administration Agreement Model Form – SDTF/MDTF”. It is important for Sida to use the new administrative agreement since the new template better reflects the Swedish law on disclosure. The new agreement also includes improved language on informing donors on incidences of suspect corruption and reporting which are both priorities to Sida’s line of working. The new administrative agreement template can only apply for new Trust Funds – or when all donors agree simultaneously to agree to transfer.  Given the significant legal differences between the 2016 template and the previous template currently used for the MPF, Sweden and other donors have exerted pressure to the World Bank to support processes to apply the new 2016 template for new contributions to the Somalia Multi-Partner Trust Fund. In order to accommodate the request by Sweden and other donors who would like to use the 2016 template and exploring different options, the WB has agreed to create a new Multi-Partner Trust Fund, referred to as ‘MPF Phase 2’. The structure of the MPF Phase 2 means that World Bank will continue to report externally in one consolidated MPF Report but internally there will be two systems across which the World Bank will have to manage the Somalia investment portfolio over a few years. This effectively means an increased administrative cost. Sida has in its decision valued the benefits of using the new agreement template despite the higher administrative the new trust fund entails. The present Trust Fund is valid until 2024 with possible extension of the period. Therefore, Sida finds it difficult to enter into a new multi-year contribution agreement with the current template that does not correspond to Swedish law. Moreover, more MPF donors are expected to gradually shift to the MPF Phase 2, whereby the costs for administration is expected to decline. Other donors have already expressed interest in joining the MPF 2 in the near future. Sweden will also assert its influence among donors and advocate the phasing out of the existing Trust Fund.

The World Bank will be overall responsible for implementation but the delivery model implies that 80-85% of MPF projects are recipient executed. This means that large shares of the funding to MPF will be channeled through the Federal Government of Somalia and Federal member states. The risk of using country systems in Somalia is considered high. However, the use of country systems maximizes the effectiveness of aid and can help government legitimacy and public support, strengthening the accountability between the State and its citizens. The World Bank does not have an office in Mogadishu yet, but are gradually increasing their presence in Somalia albeit the World Bank´s presence on the ground is limited, but the World Bank works closely with the Somali authorities, both at national and sub-national level. The World Bank deploys a third-Party Monitoring Agent to support the monitoring of the World Bank´s projects as well as supporting the Bank teams in understanding the risks and manage the risks. The third-party monitoring agent also provides targeted support to the government in rebuilding and strengthening their Public Financial Management systems.It is Sida´s assessment that the World Bank as the cooperation partner has routines, resources and competence to ensure adequate internal management and control.  

Somalia is making good progress in core reform areas such as the establishment of the Somalia Financial Management Information System, mechanisms for fiscal transfers between the federal government and federal member states, and improved central bank oversight and supervision. To date, the government has successfully conducted two Staff Monitored Program (SMP I and II) and embarked on a third SMP. Somalia has been identified as eligible for debt relief under the Highly Indebted Poor Country (HIPC) initiative given its unsustainable debt levels. The MPF shows a good track record and results which indicates that there are positive causal links between the MPF programs and the progress that Somalia has made since the establishment of the MPF. 

The WB-MPF portfolio has contributed to crucial reforms such as macroeconomic stability and building a track record for arrears clearance and debt relief. There is evidence that potential access to IFI financing, in the relatively short term, and eventual debt relief in the longer term, are proving powerful incentives for reforms, particularly in public finance management. The MPF private sector development support has been critical for business reforms and engaging the private sector. Developing the Somali private sector is imperative to Somalia’s peace and prosperity, and the government and donors need to work closely with the private sector on economic growth priorities. Nevertheless, the challenges for Somalia are still daunting in many areas such as improving macro-fiscal framework, implementing crucial tax measures to raise revenue, enacting key legislation, forging a political consensus on a federal model and strengthening the capacity of key institutions. 

Overall risk level in Somalia:
Violence and armed conflict as well as political instability are some of the main obstacles to economic and social development in Somalia. Apart from the political and security challenges, Somalia is in a difficult humanitarian situation. Climate change and recurring periods of drought regularly affect the population and its resilience is low after decades of conflict and instability. More concretely, the following general risks that can negatively affects the MPF programs have been identified:
•	Worsened security situation and increased Al-Shabaab attacks that can destabilize the country.
•	Somalia´s transition as well as clan/fraction related local conflicts.
•	High level of corruption and culture of nepotism affecting MPF programs.
•	Political instability due to the federalization process as well as upcoming elections (both FMS level and federal level).
•	Recurrent natural disasters and/or conflict might disrupt the World Bank's MPF long term development interventions where donors might have to re-prioritize or re-program available funds depending on the severity of the shocks. This might affect donor contributions to the MPF and available funds to MPF, meaning less contributions to the MPF.

The appraisal memorandum has been written in English, as English-speaking personnel at the Embassy in Nairobi participate in the appraisal and follow-up of the contribution, in accordance with the General Director's decision regarding choice of language as per the instructions from 1 March 2013.

implementing: International Bank for Reconstruction and Development
programming: IBRD/International Bank for Reconstruction and Development/The World Bank

Sida has provided support to UN-MPTF since 2015 (decision number 2015-002435 and 2018-001376). The AFDB-SIF is currently the only funding window which Sida does not contribute. The AFDB-SIF has only started in 2017.

The overall aim of the CPF 2019-2022 is to lay foundations for the longer-term poverty reduction and inclusive growth by focusing on priority areas and constraints creating the current Somalia "dual development trap" created by low level of trusts and exacerbated by widespread vulnerability of repeated shocks. The strategy has two focus areas (1) Strengthening Institutions to Deliver Services and (2) Restoring Economic Resilience and Opportunities. The first focus area will strengthen ongoing governance programs with a new focus on fiscal space and improving access to - and quality of - key social services and resilience. Programs will specifically target public finance management reforms, domestic revenue mobilization and resource sharing, basic delivery systems for social services; and urban resilience. The second focus area aims to increase economic resilience as a basis for long-run poverty reduction and inclusive growth by improving business environment and lowering barriers to market entry, increasing access to finance for inclusion and digital development; and improved access to water and renewable energy. 

Although the new World Bank strategy covers the period 2019-2022, Sida proposal for support is during 2019-2020, with a total amount of 200 million SEK as well as a support to current MPF programs of 75 million SEK in 2018. Depending if and when the World Bank manage to secure additional IDA financing and if the World Bank manages to re-adjust current plans for the health sector in line with Sida recommendations, Sida will consider contributing additional funds to the MPF during 2021-2022.

To regulate Sida’s commitment and conditions for supporting the Somalia MPF, Sida and the World Bank will use the 2016 template agreed in December 2016 by Consultative Group on Operational Principles for Trust Funds and Partnership (CGOP) “Model Form of Administration Agreement Model Form – SDTF/MDTF”. It is important for Sida to use the new administrative agreement since the new template better reflects the Swedish law on disclosure. The new agreement also includes improved language on informing donors on incidences of suspect corruption and reporting which are both priorities to Sida’s line of working. The new administrative agreement template can only apply for new Trust Funds – or when all donors agree simultaneously to agree to transfer.  Given the significant legal differences between the 2016 template and the previous template currently used for the MPF, Sweden and other donors have exerted pressure to the World Bank to support processes to apply the new 2016 template for new contributions to the Somalia Multi-Partner Trust Fund. In order to accommodate the request by Sweden and other donors who would like to use the 2016 template and exploring different options, the WB has agreed to create a new Multi-Partner Trust Fund, referred to as ‘MPF Phase 2’. The structure of the MPF Phase 2 means that World Bank will continue to report externally in one consolidated MPF Report but internally there will be two systems across which the World Bank will have to manage the Somalia investment portfolio over a few years. This effectively means an increased administrative cost. Sida has in its decision valued the benefits of using the new agreement template despite the higher administrative the new trust fund entails. The present Trust Fund is valid until 2024 with possible extension of the period. Therefore, Sida finds it difficult to enter into a new multi-year contribution agreement with the current template that does not correspond to Swedish law. Moreover, more MPF donors are expected to gradually shift to the MPF Phase 2, whereby the costs for administration is expected to decline. Other donors have already expressed interest in joining the MPF 2 in the near future. Sweden will also assert its influence among donors and advocate the phasing out of the existing Trust Fund.

The World Bank will be overall responsible for implementation but the delivery model implies that 80-85% of MPF projects are recipient executed. This means that large shares of the funding to MPF will be channeled through the Federal Government of Somalia and Federal member states. The risk of using country systems in Somalia is considered high. However, the use of country systems maximizes the effectiveness of aid and can help government legitimacy and public support, strengthening the accountability between the State and its citizens. The World Bank does not have an office in Mogadishu yet, but are gradually increasing their presence in Somalia albeit the World Bank´s presence on the ground is limited, but the World Bank works closely with the Somali authorities, both at national and sub-national level. The World Bank deploys a third-Party Monitoring Agent to support the monitoring of the World Bank´s projects as well as supporting the Bank teams in understanding the risks and manage the risks. The third-party monitoring agent also provides targeted support to the government in rebuilding and strengthening their Public Financial Management systems.It is Sida´s assessment that the World Bank as the cooperation partner has routines, resources and competence to ensure adequate internal management and control.  

Somalia is making good progress in core reform areas such as the establishment of the Somalia Financial Management Information System, mechanisms for fiscal transfers between the federal government and federal member states, and improved central bank oversight and supervision. To date, the government has successfully conducted two Staff Monitored Program (SMP I and II) and embarked on a third SMP. Somalia has been identified as eligible for debt relief under the Highly Indebted Poor Country (HIPC) initiative given its unsustainable debt levels. The MPF shows a good track record and results which indicates that there are positive causal links between the MPF programs and the progress that Somalia has made since the establishment of the MPF. 

The WB-MPF portfolio has contributed to crucial reforms such as macroeconomic stability and building a track record for arrears clearance and debt relief. There is evidence that potential access to IFI financing, in the relatively short term, and eventual debt relief in the longer term, are proving powerful incentives for reforms, particularly in public finance management. The MPF private sector development support has been critical for business reforms and engaging the private sector. Developing the Somali private sector is imperative to Somalia’s peace and prosperity, and the government and donors need to work closely with the private sector on economic growth priorities. Nevertheless, the challenges for Somalia are still daunting in many areas such as improving macro-fiscal framework, implementing crucial tax measures to raise revenue, enacting key legislation, forging a political consensus on a federal model and strengthening the capacity of key institutions. 

Overall risk level in Somalia:
Violence and armed conflict as well as political instability are some of the main obstacles to economic and social development in Somalia. Apart from the political and security challenges, Somalia is in a difficult humanitarian situation. Climate change and recurring periods of drought regularly affect the population and its resilience is low after decades of conflict and instability. More concretely, the following general risks that can negatively affects the MPF programs have been identified:
•	Worsened security situation and increased Al-Shabaab attacks that can destabilize the country.
•	Somalia´s transition as well as clan/fraction related local conflicts.
•	High level of corruption and culture of nepotism affecting MPF programs.
•	Political instability due to the federalization process as well as upcoming elections (both FMS level and federal level).
•	Recurrent natural disasters and/or conflict might disrupt the World Bank's MPF long term development interventions where donors might have to re-prioritize or re-program available funds depending on the severity of the shocks. This might affect donor contributions to the MPF and available funds to MPF, meaning less contributions to the MPF.

The appraisal memorandum has been written in English, as English-speaking personnel at the Embassy in Nairobi participate in the appraisal and follow-up of the contribution, in accordance with the General Director's decision regarding choice of language as per the instructions from 1 March 2013.

Overall risk level in Somalia:
Violence and armed conflict as well as political instability are some of the main obstacles to economic and social development in Somalia. Apart from the political and security challenges, Somalia is in a difficult humanitarian situation. Climate change and recurring periods of drought regularly affect the population and its resilience is low after decades of conflict and instability. More concretely, the following general risks that can negatively affects the MPF programs have been identified:
•	Worsened security situation and increased Al-Shabaab attacks that can destabilize the country.
•	Somalia´s transition as well as clan/fraction related local conflicts.
•	High level of corruption and culture of nepotism affecting MPF programs.
•	Political instability due to the federalization process as well as upcoming elections (both FMS level and federal level).
•	Recurrent natural disasters and/or conflict might disrupt the World Bank's MPF long term development interventions where donors might have to re-prioritize or re-program available funds depending on the severity of the shocks. This might affect donor contributions to the MPF and available funds to MPF, meaning less contributions to the MPF.

The appraisal memorandum has been written in English, as English-speaking personnel at the Embassy in Nairobi participate in the appraisal and follow-up of the contribution, in accordance with the General Director's decision regarding choice of language as per the instructions from 1 March 2013.

title: WB Multi-Partner Fund Somalia 2018-2021
description:
Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19
This intervention builds on current ongoing Sida support to the World Bank Multi-Partner Fund for Somalia (2014-2018), decision number 2014-003041. The current Sida support to the WB-MPF focus on four areas:
1. Enabling economic growth
2. Effective and accountable government
3. Urban infrastructure
4. Analytical and technical assistance.

In September 2018, the World Bank Board of Directors approved a new four-year strategy for Somalia 2019-2022. This strategy is the first World Bank strategy for Somalia in 30 years and signals a renewed confidence and trust by the World Bank in Somalia´s road map to development. This Country Partnership Framework (CPF) is currently funded by 10 donors through the the Multi-Partner Fund modality for delivery. Sweden is the fourth biggest contributor to the fund. The MPF modality is per definition a pooled fund mechanism with is the preferred mechanism of financing in conflict and post-conflict contexts. The MPF is one of three pooled funding mechanisms in Somalia established as part of the Somalia Development and Reconstruction Facility. The MPF is administered by the World Bank and operates in close cooperation with the federal government of Somalia and the contributing donors. WB-MPF are well aligned with government priorities, as articulated in the National Development Plan (2017-2019) and together cover all eight pillars of the NDP. Hence, national ownership and alignment to principles of development effectiveness is adhered to. As Administrator of the Trust Fund, the World Bank is responsible for ensuring that the MPF and its funds are used in accordance with the administrative agreements and that recipients use MPF funds in accordance with the grant agreements.

The MPF has a specific focus support to core state functions, socioeconomic recovery and sustainable development compared with the UN Fund being more broad in scope and the AfDB focusing on rehabilitation and development of infrastructure. Sida has provided support to UN-MPTF since 2015 (decision number 2015-002435 and 2018-001376). The AFDB-SIF is currently the only funding window which Sida does not contribute. The AFDB-SIF has only started in 2017.

The overall aim of the CPF 2019-2022 is to lay foundations for the longer-term poverty reduction and inclusive growth by focusing on priority areas and constraints creating the current Somalia "dual development trap" created by low level of trusts and exacerbated by widespread vulnerability of repeated shocks. The strategy has two focus areas (1) Strengthening Institutions to Deliver Services and (2) Restoring Economic Resilience and Opportunities. The first focus area will strengthen ongoing governance programs with a new focus on fiscal space and improving access to - and quality of - key social services and resilience. Programs will specifically target public finance management reforms, domestic revenue mobilization and resource sharing, basic delivery systems for social services; and urban resilience. The second focus area aims to increase economic resilience as a basis for long-run poverty reduction and inclusive growth by improving business environment and lowering barriers to market entry, increasing access to finance for inclusion and digital development; and improved access to water and renewable energy. 

Although the new World Bank strategy covers the period 2019-2022, Sida proposal for support is during 2019-2020, with a total amount of 200 million SEK as well as a support to current MPF programs of 75 million SEK in 2018. Depending if and when the World Bank manage to secure additional IDA financing and if the World Bank manages to re-adjust current plans for the health sector in line with Sida recommendations, Sida will consider contributing additional funds to the MPF during 2021-2022.

To regulate Sida’s commitment and conditions for supporting the Somalia MPF, Sida and the World Bank will use the 2016 template agreed in December 2016 by Consultative Group on Operational Principles for Trust Funds and Partnership (CGOP) “Model Form of Administration Agreement Model Form – SDTF/MDTF”. It is important for Sida to use the new administrative agreement since the new template better reflects the Swedish law on disclosure. The new agreement also includes improved language on informing donors on incidences of suspect corruption and reporting which are both priorities to Sida’s line of working. The new administrative agreement template can only apply for new Trust Funds – or when all donors agree simultaneously to agree to transfer.  Given the significant legal differences between the 2016 template and the previous template currently used for the MPF, Sweden and other donors have exerted pressure to the World Bank to support processes to apply the new 2016 template for new contributions to the Somalia Multi-Partner Trust Fund. In order to accommodate the request by Sweden and other donors who would like to use the 2016 template and exploring different options, the WB has agreed to create a new Multi-Partner Trust Fund, referred to as ‘MPF Phase 2’. The structure of the MPF Phase 2 means that World Bank will continue to report externally in one consolidated MPF Report but internally there will be two systems across which the World Bank will have to manage the Somalia investment portfolio over a few years. This effectively means an increased administrative cost. Sida has in its decision valued the benefits of using the new agreement template despite the higher administrative the new trust fund entails. The present Trust Fund is valid until 2024 with possible extension of the period. Therefore, Sida finds it difficult to enter into a new multi-year contribution agreement with the current template that does not correspond to Swedish law. Moreover, more MPF donors are expected to gradually shift to the MPF Phase 2, whereby the costs for administration is expected to decline. Other donors have already expressed interest in joining the MPF 2 in the near future. Sweden will also assert its influence among donors and advocate the phasing out of the existing Trust Fund.

The World Bank will be overall responsible for implementation but the delivery model implies that 80-85% of MPF projects are recipient executed. This means that large shares of the funding to MPF will be channeled through the Federal Government of Somalia and Federal member states. The risk of using country systems in Somalia is considered high. However, the use of country systems maximizes the effectiveness of aid and can help government legitimacy and public support, strengthening the accountability between the State and its citizens. The World Bank does not have an office in Mogadishu yet, but are gradually increasing their presence in Somalia albeit the World Bank´s presence on the ground is limited, but the World Bank works closely with the Somali authorities, both at national and sub-national level. The World Bank deploys a third-Party Monitoring Agent to support the monitoring of the World Bank´s projects as well as supporting the Bank teams in understanding the risks and manage the risks. The third-party monitoring agent also provides targeted support to the government in rebuilding and strengthening their Public Financial Management systems.It is Sida´s assessment that the World Bank as the cooperation partner has routines, resources and competence to ensure adequate internal management and control.  

Somalia is making good progress in core reform areas such as the establishment of the Somalia Financial Management Information System, mechanisms for fiscal transfers between the federal government and federal member states, and improved central bank oversight and supervision. To date, the government has successfully conducted two Staff Monitored Program (SMP I and II) and embarked on a third SMP. Somalia has been identified as eligible for debt relief under the Highly Indebted Poor Country (HIPC) initiative given its unsustainable debt levels. The MPF shows a good track record and results which indicates that there are positive causal links between the MPF programs and the progress that Somalia has made since the establishment of the MPF. 

The WB-MPF portfolio has contributed to crucial reforms such as macroeconomic stability and building a track record for arrears clearance and debt relief. There is evidence that potential access to IFI financing, in the relatively short term, and eventual debt relief in the longer term, are proving powerful incentives for reforms, particularly in public finance management. The MPF private sector development support has been critical for business reforms and engaging the private sector. Developing the Somali private sector is imperative to Somalia’s peace and prosperity, and the government and donors need to work closely with the private sector on economic growth priorities. Nevertheless, the challenges for Somalia are still daunting in many areas such as improving macro-fiscal framework, implementing crucial tax measures to raise revenue, enacting key legislation, forging a political consensus on a federal model and strengthening the capacity of key institutions. 

Overall risk level in Somalia:
Violence and armed conflict as well as political instability are some of the main obstacles to economic and social development in Somalia. Apart from the political and security challenges, Somalia is in a difficult humanitarian situation. Climate change and recurring periods of drought regularly affect the population and its resilience is low after decades of conflict and instability. More concretely, the following general risks that can negatively affects the MPF programs have been identified:
•	Worsened security situation and increased Al-Shabaab attacks that can destabilize the country.
•	Somalia´s transition as well as clan/fraction related local conflicts.
•	High level of corruption and culture of nepotism affecting MPF programs.
•	Political instability due to the federalization process as well as upcoming elections (both FMS level and federal level).
•	Recurrent natural disasters and/or conflict might disrupt the World Bank's MPF long term development interventions where donors might have to re-prioritize or re-program available funds depending on the severity of the shocks. This might affect donor contributions to the MPF and available funds to MPF, meaning less contributions to the MPF.

The appraisal memorandum has been written in English, as English-speaking personnel at the Embassy in Nairobi participate in the appraisal and follow-up of the contribution, in accordance with the General Director's decision regarding choice of language as per the instructions from 1 March 2013.

The structure of the MPF Phase 2 means that World Bank will continue to report externally in one consolidated MPF Report but internally there will be two systems across which the World Bank will have to manage the Somalia investment portfolio over a few years. This effectively means an increased administrative cost. Sida has in its decision valued the benefits of using the new agreement template despite the higher administrative the new trust fund entails. The present Trust Fund is valid until 2024 with possible extension of the period. Therefore, Sida finds it difficult to enter into a new multi-year contribution agreement with the current template that does not correspond to Swedish law. Moreover, more MPF donors are expected to gradually shift to the MPF Phase 2, whereby the costs for administration is expected to decline. Other donors have already expressed interest in joining the MPF 2 in the near future. Sweden will also assert its influence among donors and advocate the phasing out of the existing Trust Fund.

The World Bank will be overall responsible for implementation but the delivery model implies that 80-85% of MPF projects are recipient executed. This means that large shares of the funding to MPF will be channeled through the Federal Government of Somalia and Federal member states. The risk of using country systems in Somalia is considered high. However, the use of country systems maximizes the effectiveness of aid and can help government legitimacy and public support, strengthening the accountability between the State and its citizens. The World Bank does not have an office in Mogadishu yet, but are gradually increasing their presence in Somalia albeit the World Bank´s presence on the ground is limited, but the World Bank works closely with the Somali authorities, both at national and sub-national level. The World Bank deploys a third-Party Monitoring Agent to support the monitoring of the World Bank´s projects as well as supporting the Bank teams in understanding the risks and manage the risks. The third-party monitoring agent also provides targeted support to the government in rebuilding and strengthening their Public Financial Management systems.It is Sida´s assessment that the World Bank as the cooperation partner has routines, resources and competence to ensure adequate internal management and control.  

Somalia is making good progress in core reform areas such as the establishment of the Somalia Financial Management Information System, mechanisms for fiscal transfers between the federal government and federal member states, and improved central bank oversight and supervision. To date, the government has successfully conducted two Staff Monitored Program (SMP I and II) and embarked on a third SMP. Somalia has been identified as eligible for debt relief under the Highly Indebted Poor Country (HIPC) initiative given its unsustainable debt levels. The MPF shows a good track record and results which indicates that there are positive causal links between the MPF programs and the progress that Somalia has made since the establishment of the MPF. 

The WB-MPF portfolio has contributed to crucial reforms such as macroeconomic stability and building a track record for arrears clearance and debt relief. There is evidence that potential access to IFI financing, in the relatively short term, and eventual debt relief in the longer term, are proving powerful incentives for reforms, particularly in public finance management. The MPF private sector development support has been critical for business reforms and engaging the private sector. Developing the Somali private sector is imperative to Somalia’s peace and prosperity, and the government and donors need to work closely with the private sector on economic growth priorities. Nevertheless, the challenges for Somalia are still daunting in many areas such as improving macro-fiscal framework, implementing crucial tax measures to raise revenue, enacting key legislation, forging a political consensus on a federal model and strengthening the capacity of key institutions. 

Overall risk level in Somalia:
Violence and armed conflict as well as political instability are some of the main obstacles to economic and social development in Somalia. Apart from the political and security challenges, Somalia is in a difficult humanitarian situation. Climate change and recurring periods of drought regularly affect the population and its resilience is low after decades of conflict and instability. More concretely, the following general risks that can negatively affects the MPF programs have been identified:
•	Worsened security situation and increased Al-Shabaab attacks that can destabilize the country.
•	Somalia´s transition as well as clan/fraction related local conflicts.
•	High level of corruption and culture of nepotism affecting MPF programs.
•	Political instability due to the federalization process as well as upcoming elections (both FMS level and federal level).
•	Recurrent natural disasters and/or conflict might disrupt the World Bank's MPF long term development interventions where donors might have to re-prioritize or re-program available funds depending on the severity of the shocks. This might affect donor contributions to the MPF and available funds to MPF, meaning less contributions to the MPF.

The appraisal memorandum has been written in English, as English-speaking personnel at the Embassy in Nairobi participate in the appraisal and follow-up of the contribution, in accordance with the General Director's decision regarding choice of language as per the instructions from 1 March 2013.

title: WB Multi-Partner Fund Somalia 2018-2021
description:
Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19
This intervention builds on current ongoing Sida support to the World Bank Multi-Partner Fund for Somalia (2014-2018), decision number 2014-003041. The current Sida support to the WB-MPF focus on four areas:
1. Enabling economic growth
2. Effective and accountable government
3. Urban infrastructure
4. Analytical and technical assistance.

In September 2018, the World Bank Board of Directors approved a new four-year strategy for Somalia 2019-2022. This strategy is the first World Bank strategy for Somalia in 30 years and signals a renewed confidence and trust by the World Bank in Somalia´s road map to development. This Country Partnership Framework (CPF) is currently funded by 10 donors through the the Multi-Partner Fund modality for delivery. Sweden is the fourth biggest contributor to the fund. The MPF modality is per definition a pooled fund mechanism with is the preferred mechanism of financing in conflict and post-conflict contexts. The MPF is one of three pooled funding mechanisms in Somalia established as part of the Somalia Development and Reconstruction Facility. The MPF is administered by the World Bank and operates in close cooperation with the federal government of Somalia and the contributing donors. WB-MPF are well aligned with government priorities, as articulated in the National Development Plan (2017-2019) and together cover all eight pillars of the NDP. Hence, national ownership and alignment to principles of development effectiveness is adhered to. As Administrator of the Trust Fund, the World Bank is responsible for ensuring that the MPF and its funds are used in accordance with the administrative agreements and that recipients use MPF funds in accordance with the grant agreements.

The MPF has a specific focus support to core state functions, socioeconomic recovery and sustainable development compared with the UN Fund being more broad in scope and the AfDB focusing on rehabilitation and development of infrastructure. Sida has provided support to UN-MPTF since 2015 (decision number 2015-002435 and 2018-001376). The AFDB-SIF is currently the only funding window which Sida does not contribute. The AFDB-SIF has only started in 2017.

The overall aim of the CPF 2019-2022 is to lay foundations for the longer-term poverty reduction and inclusive growth by focusing on priority areas and constraints creating the current Somalia "dual development trap" created by low level of trusts and exacerbated by widespread vulnerability of repeated shocks. The strategy has two focus areas (1) Strengthening Institutions to Deliver Services and (2) Restoring Economic Resilience and Opportunities. The first focus area will strengthen ongoing governance programs with a new focus on fiscal space and improving access to - and quality of - key social services and resilience. Programs will specifically target public finance management reforms, domestic revenue mobilization and resource sharing, basic delivery systems for social services; and urban resilience. The second focus area aims to increase economic resilience as a basis for long-run poverty reduction and inclusive growth by improving business environment and lowering barriers to market entry, increasing access to finance for inclusion and digital development; and improved access to water and renewable energy. 

Although the new World Bank strategy covers the period 2019-2022, Sida proposal for support is during 2019-2020, with a total amount of 200 million SEK as well as a support to current MPF programs of 75 million SEK in 2018. Depending if and when the World Bank manage to secure additional IDA financing and if the World Bank manages to re-adjust current plans for the health sector in line with Sida recommendations, Sida will consider contributing additional funds to the MPF during 2021-2022.

To regulate Sida’s commitment and conditions for supporting the Somalia MPF, Sida and the World Bank will use the 2016 template agreed in December 2016 by Consultative Group on Operational Principles for Trust Funds and Partnership (CGOP) “Model Form of Administration Agreement Model Form – SDTF/MDTF”. It is important for Sida to use the new administrative agreement since the new template better reflects the Swedish law on disclosure. The new agreement also includes improved language on informing donors on incidences of suspect corruption and reporting which are both priorities to Sida’s line of working. The new administrative agreement template can only apply for new Trust Funds – or when all donors agree simultaneously to agree to transfer.  Given the significant legal differences between the 2016 template and the previous template currently used for the MPF, Sweden and other donors have exerted pressure to the World Bank to support processes to apply the new 2016 template for new contributions to the Somalia Multi-Partner Trust Fund. In order to accommodate the request by Sweden and other donors who would like to use the 2016 template and exploring different options, the WB has agreed to create a new Multi-Partner Trust Fund, referred to as ‘MPF Phase 2’. The structure of the MPF Phase 2 means that World Bank will continue to report externally in one consolidated MPF Report but internally there will be two systems across which the World Bank will have to manage the Somalia investment portfolio over a few years. This effectively means an increased administrative cost. Sida has in its decision valued the benefits of using the new agreement template despite the higher administrative the new trust fund entails. The present Trust Fund is valid until 2024 with possible extension of the period. Therefore, Sida finds it difficult to enter into a new multi-year contribution agreement with the current template that does not correspond to Swedish law. Moreover, more MPF donors are expected to gradually shift to the MPF Phase 2, whereby the costs for administration is expected to decline. Other donors have already expressed interest in joining the MPF 2 in the near future. Sweden will also assert its influence among donors and advocate the phasing out of the existing Trust Fund.

The World Bank will be overall responsible for implementation but the delivery model implies that 80-85% of MPF projects are recipient executed. This means that large shares of the funding to MPF will be channeled through the Federal Government of Somalia and Federal member states. The risk of using country systems in Somalia is considered high. However, the use of country systems maximizes the effectiveness of aid and can help government legitimacy and public support, strengthening the accountability between the State and its citizens. The World Bank does not have an office in Mogadishu yet, but are gradually increasing their presence in Somalia albeit the World Bank´s presence on the ground is limited, but the World Bank works closely with the Somali authorities, both at national and sub-national level. The World Bank deploys a third-Party Monitoring Agent to support the monitoring of the World Bank´s projects as well as supporting the Bank teams in understanding the risks and manage the risks. The third-party monitoring agent also provides targeted support to the government in rebuilding and strengthening their Public Financial Management systems.It is Sida´s assessment that the World Bank as the cooperation partner has routines, resources and competence to ensure adequate internal management and control.  

Somalia is making good progress in core reform areas such as the establishment of the Somalia Financial Management Information System, mechanisms for fiscal transfers between the federal government and federal member states, and improved central bank oversight and supervision. To date, the government has successfully conducted two Staff Monitored Program (SMP I and II) and embarked on a third SMP. Somalia has been identified as eligible for debt relief under the Highly Indebted Poor Country (HIPC) initiative given its unsustainable debt levels. The MPF shows a good track record and results which indicates that there are positive causal links between the MPF programs and the progress that Somalia has made since the establishment of the MPF. 

The WB-MPF portfolio has contributed to crucial reforms such as macroeconomic stability and building a track record for arrears clearance and debt relief. There is evidence that potential access to IFI financing, in the relatively short term, and eventual debt relief in the longer term, are proving powerful incentives for reforms, particularly in public finance management. The MPF private sector development support has been critical for business reforms and engaging the private sector. Developing the Somali private sector is imperative to Somalia’s peace and prosperity, and the government and donors need to work closely with the private sector on economic growth priorities. Nevertheless, the challenges for Somalia are still daunting in many areas such as improving macro-fiscal framework, implementing crucial tax measures to raise revenue, enacting key legislation, forging a political consensus on a federal model and strengthening the capacity of key institutions. 

Overall risk level in Somalia:
Violence and armed conflict as well as political instability are some of the main obstacles to economic and social development in Somalia. Apart from the political and security challenges, Somalia is in a difficult humanitarian situation. Climate change and recurring periods of drought regularly affect the population and its resilience is low after decades of conflict and instability. More concretely, the following general risks that can negatively affects the MPF programs have been identified:
•	Worsened security situation and increased Al-Shabaab attacks that can destabilize the country.
•	Somalia´s transition as well as clan/fraction related local conflicts.
•	High level of corruption and culture of nepotism affecting MPF programs.
•	Political instability due to the federalization process as well as upcoming elections (both FMS level and federal level).
•	Recurrent natural disasters and/or conflict might disrupt the World Bank's MPF long term development interventions where donors might have to re-prioritize or re-program available funds depending on the severity of the shocks. This might affect donor contributions to the MPF and available funds to MPF, meaning less contributions to the MPF.

This Country Partnership Framework (CPF) is currently funded by 10 donors through the the Multi-Partner Fund modality for delivery. Sweden is the fourth biggest contributor to the fund. The MPF modality is per definition a pooled fund mechanism with is the preferred mechanism of financing in conflict and post-conflict contexts. The MPF is one of three pooled funding mechanisms in Somalia established as part of the Somalia Development and Reconstruction Facility. The MPF is administered by the World Bank and operates in close cooperation with the federal government of Somalia and the contributing donors. WB-MPF are well aligned with government priorities, as articulated in the National Development Plan (2017-2019) and together cover all eight pillars of the NDP. Hence, national ownership and alignment to principles of development effectiveness is adhered to. As Administrator of the Trust Fund, the World Bank is responsible for ensuring that the MPF and its funds are used in accordance with the administrative agreements and that recipients use MPF funds in accordance with the grant agreements.

The MPF has a specific focus support to core state functions, socioeconomic recovery and sustainable development compared with the UN Fund being more broad in scope and the AfDB focusing on rehabilitation and development of infrastructure. Sida has provided support to UN-MPTF since 2015 (decision number 2015-002435 and 2018-001376). The AFDB-SIF is currently the only funding window which Sida does not contribute. The AFDB-SIF has only started in 2017.

The overall aim of the CPF 2019-2022 is to lay foundations for the longer-term poverty reduction and inclusive growth by focusing on priority areas and constraints creating the current Somalia "dual development trap" created by low level of trusts and exacerbated by widespread vulnerability of repeated shocks. The strategy has two focus areas (1) Strengthening Institutions to Deliver Services and (2) Restoring Economic Resilience and Opportunities. The first focus area will strengthen ongoing governance programs with a new focus on fiscal space and improving access to - and quality of - key social services and resilience. Programs will specifically target public finance management reforms, domestic revenue mobilization and resource sharing, basic delivery systems for social services; and urban resilience. The second focus area aims to increase economic resilience as a basis for long-run poverty reduction and inclusive growth by improving business environment and lowering barriers to market entry, increasing access to finance for inclusion and digital development; and improved access to water and renewable energy. 

Although the new World Bank strategy covers the period 2019-2022, Sida proposal for support is during 2019-2020, with a total amount of 200 million SEK as well as a support to current MPF programs of 75 million SEK in 2018. Depending if and when the World Bank manage to secure additional IDA financing and if the World Bank manages to re-adjust current plans for the health sector in line with Sida recommendations, Sida will consider contributing additional funds to the MPF during 2021-2022.

To regulate Sida’s commitment and conditions for supporting the Somalia MPF, Sida and the World Bank will use the 2016 template agreed in December 2016 by Consultative Group on Operational Principles for Trust Funds and Partnership (CGOP) “Model Form of Administration Agreement Model Form – SDTF/MDTF”. It is important for Sida to use the new administrative agreement since the new template better reflects the Swedish law on disclosure. The new agreement also includes improved language on informing donors on incidences of suspect corruption and reporting which are both priorities to Sida’s line of working. The new administrative agreement template can only apply for new Trust Funds – or when all donors agree simultaneously to agree to transfer.  Given the significant legal differences between the 2016 template and the previous template currently used for the MPF, Sweden and other donors have exerted pressure to the World Bank to support processes to apply the new 2016 template for new contributions to the Somalia Multi-Partner Trust Fund. In order to accommodate the request by Sweden and other donors who would like to use the 2016 template and exploring different options, the WB has agreed to create a new Multi-Partner Trust Fund, referred to as ‘MPF Phase 2’. The structure of the MPF Phase 2 means that World Bank will continue to report externally in one consolidated MPF Report but internally there will be two systems across which the World Bank will have to manage the Somalia investment portfolio over a few years. This effectively means an increased administrative cost. Sida has in its decision valued the benefits of using the new agreement template despite the higher administrative the new trust fund entails. The present Trust Fund is valid until 2024 with possible extension of the period. Therefore, Sida finds it difficult to enter into a new multi-year contribution agreement with the current template that does not correspond to Swedish law. Moreover, more MPF donors are expected to gradually shift to the MPF Phase 2, whereby the costs for administration is expected to decline. Other donors have already expressed interest in joining the MPF 2 in the near future. Sweden will also assert its influence among donors and advocate the phasing out of the existing Trust Fund.

The World Bank will be overall responsible for implementation but the delivery model implies that 80-85% of MPF projects are recipient executed. This means that large shares of the funding to MPF will be channeled through the Federal Government of Somalia and Federal member states. The risk of using country systems in Somalia is considered high. However, the use of country systems maximizes the effectiveness of aid and can help government legitimacy and public support, strengthening the accountability between the State and its citizens. The World Bank does not have an office in Mogadishu yet, but are gradually increasing their presence in Somalia albeit the World Bank´s presence on the ground is limited, but the World Bank works closely with the Somali authorities, both at national and sub-national level. The World Bank deploys a third-Party Monitoring Agent to support the monitoring of the World Bank´s projects as well as supporting the Bank teams in understanding the risks and manage the risks. The third-party monitoring agent also provides targeted support to the government in rebuilding and strengthening their Public Financial Management systems.It is Sida´s assessment that the World Bank as the cooperation partner has routines, resources and competence to ensure adequate internal management and control.  

Somalia is making good progress in core reform areas such as the establishment of the Somalia Financial Management Information System, mechanisms for fiscal transfers between the federal government and federal member states, and improved central bank oversight and supervision. To date, the government has successfully conducted two Staff Monitored Program (SMP I and II) and embarked on a third SMP. Somalia has been identified as eligible for debt relief under the Highly Indebted Poor Country (HIPC) initiative given its unsustainable debt levels. The MPF shows a good track record and results which indicates that there are positive causal links between the MPF programs and the progress that Somalia has made since the establishment of the MPF. 

The WB-MPF portfolio has contributed to crucial reforms such as macroeconomic stability and building a track record for arrears clearance and debt relief. There is evidence that potential access to IFI financing, in the relatively short term, and eventual debt relief in the longer term, are proving powerful incentives for reforms, particularly in public finance management. The MPF private sector development support has been critical for business reforms and engaging the private sector. Developing the Somali private sector is imperative to Somalia’s peace and prosperity, and the government and donors need to work closely with the private sector on economic growth priorities. Nevertheless, the challenges for Somalia are still daunting in many areas such as improving macro-fiscal framework, implementing crucial tax measures to raise revenue, enacting key legislation, forging a political consensus on a federal model and strengthening the capacity of key institutions. 

Overall risk level in Somalia:
Violence and armed conflict as well as political instability are some of the main obstacles to economic and social development in Somalia. Apart from the political and security challenges, Somalia is in a difficult humanitarian situation. Climate change and recurring periods of drought regularly affect the population and its resilience is low after decades of conflict and instability. More concretely, the following general risks that can negatively affects the MPF programs have been identified:
•	Worsened security situation and increased Al-Shabaab attacks that can destabilize the country.
•	Somalia´s transition as well as clan/fraction related local conflicts.
•	High level of corruption and culture of nepotism affecting MPF programs.
•	Political instability due to the federalization process as well as upcoming elections (both FMS level and federal level).
•	Recurrent natural disasters and/or conflict might disrupt the World Bank's MPF long term development interventions where donors might have to re-prioritize or re-program available funds depending on the severity of the shocks. This might affect donor contributions to the MPF and available funds to MPF, meaning less contributions to the MPF.

The appraisal memorandum has been written in English, as English-speaking personnel at the Embassy in Nairobi participate in the appraisal and follow-up of the contribution, in accordance with the General Director's decision regarding choice of language as per the instructions from 1 March 2013.

title: Somalia JHNP 2014-2016
description:
UNICEF, as the management agent for the Joint Health and Nutrition Programme (JHNP) for Somalia, has applied to Sida for MSEK 210 to fund and implement the programme during the remaining part of the strategic period of the programme; 2014-2016. Sweden has previously contributed with 64 MSEK to the programme during 2012-2013. The intervention aims at improving the health and nutrition status of the Somali people and thus contributing to reduction in maternal and child mortality by increasing the use of Reproductive Maternal Neonatal Child Health (RMNCH) and nutrition services that are accessible, available, affordable, of acceptable quality and affordable.

The intervention adopts the Health Systems Strengthening approach and will: 1) Improve governance and leadership at all levels of the health sector; 2) Ensure skilled and motivated health workforce that is distributed equally and equipped to deliver quality RMNCH and nutrition services through a continuum of care; 3) Ensure RMNCH and Nutrition services available, accessible, affordable, of acceptable quality and adaptable, within the Essential Package of Health Services (EPHS) framework; 4) Improve access, availability, quality and rational use of essential medicines, vaccines and medical equipment and physical structures; 5) Improve access, availability, acceptability, quality and use of health information that covers disease surveillance as well as management information system; and 6) Promote steady progress to an equitable and efficient health financing system.

The Somali Health Authorities (consisting of the Federal Ministry of Health for the Somali Republic as well as the Ministries of Health in Somaliland and Puntland) owns the program, UNICEF is the management agent and hence the contracting administrative agent for this joint-UN programme, where also WHO and UNFPA support the operationalization of the programme. The programme is overseen by the Somali Health Sector Committee with technical back-stopping through the Health Advisory Board. 

The intervention’s total budget is MSEK 1 522 for 2014-2016. Current donors that have committed support to the programme are Sida, DFID, USAID and the Swiss Development Cooperation (SDC). The current total funding commitments for 2014-2016 amount to approximately 50% of the planned budget. Implementation of the programme is planned in accordance to available funding. A health finance strategy is about to be finalized that will be used to mobilize remaining needed resources to take the programme to its full potential.

title: Somalia Credit Guarantee Scheme (SCGS)
description:
The intervention targets several development problems in Somalia. The financial sector in Somalia is underdeveloped. Banks practice an exclusive approach towards lending that only occurs to the few that can provide collateral. Financing costs are high and allow only short-term financing. The majority of the population, and especially women and young people, are excluded from the financial sector due to lack of collateral and perceived risk level. This in turn has a major negative impact on micro, small and medium sized businesses, MSMEs and its conditions for employment and creating jobs. This initiative is expected to open up for access to finance for MSMEs, thereby contributing to job creation, especially for women and youth, in Somalia.
Several on-going programs, including the World Bank's Somalia Core Economic Institutions and Opportunities Program (SCORE), supported by Sweden among several other donors, work to address issues related to the legal framework and legal review, as well as formalization of the financial sector, but no intervention is targeting the problem of access to finance and cost of credit. The biggest casualties of this are MSME's which are widely recognized as key drivers of new job creation and overall economic growth. Therefore, the objective of this intervention is to reduce poverty in Somalia through enterprise growth and employment creation. MSME, especially with focus on women and young people, will be able to benefit from formal banking system and the Somali financial will be able to benefit from more long-term clients, which in turn will provide much needed growth capital for expansion, employment and contribute to resilience. 
In the long run, it is expected to contribute to a change in Financial Institutions' lending attitudes to include a broader segment of clients and recognize on their part that this makes good business sense. For MSMEs this is expected to provide resources for sustainable job creation as they benefit from what can become a long-term relationship with the financial institutions.
The intervention intends to provide credit guarantees in order to incentivize lending to merit worthy MSME applicants in any sector that lack sufficient collateral. To achieve this, Sida will provide a guarantee to One Earth Future Foundation (OEF), which will be Sida's agreement partner. OEF is an American NGO with projects in Somalia, among other fragile countries. The work in Somalia is handled under a project called Shuraako. Shuraako work to facilitate investments in promising Somali-based businesses. OEF will in turn sign separate agreements with the three (out of currently six) Somali financial institutions: Dahabshil Bank, Premier Bank and International Bank of Somalia, but additional financial institutions may be added during the guarantee period.
The three banks are the ones who give loans to the target group by utilizing the risk sharing set-up of the guarantee. The guarantee to OEF means that the banks´ risk is reduced for up to 70% in case the loan is not repaid while the bank takes the remaining 30%. OEF estimates that approximately 260 loans will be guaranteed and over 2000 jobs will be created during the five-year project period.
This 5 million USD Guarantee is complemented by a grant to OEF for Technical Assistance (TA) that will be provided to the banks and MSMEs, including OEFs operational costs for managing and following up the guarantee instrument. The grant component is considered essential for achieving the goal of this intervention. The Guarantee instrument and Grant component will be handled in two separate agreements where the Grant Agreement is handled by the Embassy.

title: WFP and FAO Joint Resilience Programme in Somalia
description:
This joint intervention between WFP and FAO together with the Ministry of Agriculture and Irrigation (MoAI) and the farmers’ cooperatives will  consolidates and complements FAO and WFP past and ongoing interventions for enhancing livelihoods, resilience and economic development. The project will combine capacity building support to smallholders and private sector organizations to enhance rural services based on public-private collaboration, creating better job opportunities, income, and livelihoods for smallholder farmers in selected agricultural crop value chains. 

This project complements the ongoing work by FAO and WFP with cooperatives in rain-fed and riverine farming in Somalia that is addressing crop production, productivity, quality and market access issues. The project will strengthen the resilience of riverine and agro pastoralist by building their capacities to absorb and adapt to shocks and stressors in the food system. The project will also have a transformative effect on the resilience of food systems by supporting the development of sustainable local institutions to manage food production, post-harvest management and marketing. Further, the project will support development of the target value chains to improve effectiveness and efficiency.

The outcome of the proposed project will be to enhance food and nutrition security and incomes therefore improving resilience of communities to threats and crises. Within the rain-fed and riverine areas, the project will support 20 farming cooperatives, of up to 250 smallholder farmers in each group. These cooperatives will provide farmers the opportunity to move beyond subsistence farming with access to high quality inputs, extension services and links to high value market actors. By aggregating their supply and production needs, these farmer groups can achieve the economies of scale needed to access more profitable markets. When properly equipped and managed, farmer groups act as shock absorbers in times of crisis – through savings schemes, pooled resources and other support mechanisms.
