title: Verbesserung der Lebensbedingungen in urbanen Räumen und Verbesserung der Integration von Rückkehrern (MPF)
description: Im Rahmen des Vorhabens soll die städtische Infrastruktur in den Städten Mogadischu, Baidoa und Kismayo in Südzentral-Somalia verbessert und so ein Beitrag zur Verbesserung der Lebensbedingungen der Bevölkerung, dort angesiedelter Binnenflüchtlinge sowie der aus Dadaab zurückkehrenden Flüchtlinge geleistet werden. Darüber hinaus trägt das Projekt zur Stabilisierung der fragilen Sicherheitslage in den Projektstädten Südzentral-Somalias bei und fördert so die Friedenskonsolidierung vor Ort, wie im Marshallplan mit Afrika, "Afrika und Europa - Neue Partnerschaft für Entwicklung, Frieden und Zukunft" gefordert. Der Ansatz zielt auf die Verbesserung sozialer und produktiver Infrastruktur und ist multisektoral, sodass Maßnahmen in den Bereichen Transport, Wasser- und Sanitärversorgung, Müllentsorgung, Bildung und Gesundheit möglich sind. In Mogadischu wurden bereits Maßnahmen im Bereich kommunale Infrastruktur identifiziert, für die Städte Kismayo und Baidoa wurden bereits Vorstudien erstellt. Die einzelnen Maßnahmen werden im Rahmen der Umsetzung festgelegt. Œ ŒZur Planung und Umsetzung der o.g. Maßnahmen werden die Strukturen des Multi Partner Fund der Weltbank (MPF) genutzt, der zur Umsetzung der FZ-Mittel ein gesondertes Finanzierungsfenster für städtische Infrastruktur einrichtet. Zur Förderung des von der Gebergemeinschaft angestrebten "State-Building" werden somalische Regierungsstrukturen soweit wie möglich in die Planung, Gestaltung und Umsetzung der Maßnahmen eingebunden. Auch die direkte Anbindung an den nationalen Entwicklungsplan ist damit sichergestellt. Zur Finanzierung des Vorhabens stellt das BMZ insgesamt 23,24 Mio. EUR aus FZ-Altmitteln und einer neuen bilateralen Zusage bereit. Angesichts der großen Bedarfe in den drei Projektstädten erfolgte darüber hinaus eine Vorratsprüfung in Höhe von 50 Mio. EUR. Œ

title: Resilienzförderung durch den Aufbau von Bildungsdienstleistungen in Zentral- und Süd-Somalia
description: Ziel des Vorhabens ist es, Kindern und Jugendlichen einen verbesserten Zugang zu Grundbildung und qualitativen frühkindlichen Entwicklungsangeboten sowie einen verbesserter Zugang zu angemessenen Basisdienstleistungen, insbesondere im Bereich Ernährungssicherung, zu bieten. Zusätzlich werden pilothaft qualitative, frühkindliche Entwicklungsangebote an Schulen eingeführt und Gemeinden, Föderalregierungen, Mitglieder des Föderalstaats und die Regierung von Banadir in ihren Kapazitäten gestärkt, um integrierte Bildungsdienstleistungen für Kinder und Jugendliche anzubieten. Durch die Förderung von grundlegender Schulbildung, Bildungsangeboten für Jugendliche, sowie innovativer Ernährungsprogramme an Schulen, nicht zuletzt als Anreiz für einen kontinuierlichen Schulbesuch, kann ein grundlegender Beitrag zur Förderung der Resilienz vernachlässigter Kinder und Jugendlicher in der strukturschwächsten Region Somalias geleistet werden. Dadurch erlangte gestärkte Fähigkeiten, Wissen und Selbständigkeit befähigen die Bevölkerung sich ein gesünderes und produktiveres Leben zu ermöglichen und eine erhöhte Resilienz gegenüber Not- und Konfliktsituationen zu erlangen.

title: Resilienzförderung durch den Aufbau von Bildungsdienstleistungen in Zentral- und Süd-Somalia
description: Ziel des Vorhabens ist es, Kindern und Jugendlichen einen verbesserten Zugang zu Grundbildung und qualitativen frühkindlichen Entwicklungsangeboten sowie einen verbesserter Zugang zu angemessenen Basisdienstleistungen, insbesondere im Bereich Ernährungssicherung, zu bieten. Zusätzlich werden pilothaft qualitative, frühkindliche Entwicklungsangebote an Schulen eingeführt und Gemeinden, Föderalregierungen, Mitglieder des Föderalstaats und die Regierung von Banadir in ihren Kapazitäten gestärkt, um integrierte Bildungsdienstleistungen für Kinder und Jugendliche anzubieten. Durch die Förderung von grundlegender Schulbildung, Bildungsangeboten für Jugendliche, sowie innovativer Ernährungsprogramme an Schulen, nicht zuletzt als Anreiz für einen kontinuierlichen Schulbesuch, kann ein grundlegender Beitrag zur Förderung der Resilienz vernachlässigter Kinder und Jugendlicher in der strukturschwächsten Region Somalias geleistet werden. Dadurch erlangte gestärkte Fähigkeiten, Wissen und Selbständigkeit befähigen die Bevölkerung sich ein gesünderes und produktiveres Leben zu ermöglichen und eine erhöhte Resilienz gegenüber Not- und Konfliktsituationen zu erlangen.

title: Verbesserung der Lebensbedingungen in urbanen Räumen und Verbesserung der Integration von Rückkehrern (MPF), Phase II
description: Im Rahmen des Vorhabens soll die städtische Infrastruktur in den Städten Mogadischu, Baidoa und Kismayo in Südzentral-Somalia verbessert und so ein Beitrag zur Verbesserung der Lebensbedingungen der Bevölkerung, dort angesiedelter Binnenflüchtlinge sowie der aus Dadaab zurückkehrenden Flüchtlinge geleistet werden. Darüber hinaus trägt das Projekt zur Stabilisierung der fragilen Sicherheitslage in den Projektstädten Südzentral-Somalias bei und fördert so die Friedenskonsolidierung vor Ort, wie im Marshallplan mit Afrika, "Afrika und Europa - Neue Partnerschaft für Entwicklung, Frieden und Zukunft" gefordert. Der Ansatz zielt auf die Verbesserung sozialer und produktiver Infrastruktur und ist multisektoral, sodass Maßnahmen in den Bereichen Transport, Wasser- und Sanitärversorgung, Müllentsorgung, Bildung und Gesundheit möglich sind. In Mogadischu wurden bereits Maßnahmen im Bereich kommunale Infrastruktur identifiziert, für die Städte Kismayo und Baidoa wurden Vorstudien erstellt. Die einzelnen Maßnahmen werden im Rahmen der Umsetzung festgelegt. Œ ŒZur Planung und Umsetzung der o.g. Maßnahmen werden die Strukturen des Multi Partner Fund der Weltbank (MPF) genutzt, der zur Umsetzung der FZ-Mittel ein gesondertes Finanzierungsfenster für städtische Infrastruktur einrichtet. Zur Förderung des von der Gebergemeinschaft angestrebten "State-Building" werden somalische Regierungsstrukturen soweit wie möglich in die Planung, Gestaltung und Umsetzung der Maßnahmen eingebunden. Auch die direkte Anbindung an den nationalen Entwicklungsplan ist damit sichergestellt.

title: Unterstützung landwirtschaftlicher Produktion und Qualitätssicherung
description: Die Rahmenbedingungen für die Steigerung der Produktion qualitativ hochwertiger Produkte in Somalia sind verbessert.

title: Beschäftigungsförderung für IDPs, Rückkehrer und aufnehmende Gemeinden durch arbeitsintensive Infrastrukturmaßnahmen
description: Im Rahmen des Vorhabens soll für Binnenvertriebene, Rückkehrer und aufnehmende Gemeinden ein verbesserter Zugang zu grundlegenden wirtschaftlichen und sozialen Dienstleistungen und Beschäftigungsmöglichkeiten geschaffen werden. Dabei liegt der Fokus auf der Rehabilitierung von überwiegend produktiver Infrastruktur, wie Straßen, Drainage und Beleuchtung. Durch eine verbesserte produktive Infrastruktur in und anschließend an Siedlungen von Binnenvertriebenen, Rückkehrern und umliegenden Gemeinden leistet das Vorhaben einen Beitrag zur Verbesserung der Lebensbedingungen der lokalen Bevölkerung. Eine arbeitsintensive Umsetzung der Infrastrukturmaßnahmen trägt zur Schaffung kurzfristiger Beschäftigungsmöglichkeiten für Binnenvertriebene, Rückkehrer und Mitglieder aus aufnehmenden Gemeinden bei und steigert deren ökonomischen Status. Das Vorhaben leistet zudem einen Beitrag zur Stabilisierung der fragilen Sicherheitslage und Friedenskonsolidierung vor Ort wie in der 2. Säule des Marshallplans mit Afrika "Frieden, Sicherheit und Stabilität" gefordert.

title: Unterstützung Multipartner Trust Fund - Stärkung der wirtschaftlichen Entwicklung in urbanen Räumen
description: Im Rahmen des Vorhabens soll die städtische Infrastruktur in Städten in Südzentral-Somalia (Mogadischu, Baidoa und Kismayo) sowie Puntland (Garowe) verbessert werden. Das Projekt zielt darauf ab, einen Beitrag zur Verbesserung der Lebensbedingungen der Bevölkerung und dort angesiedelter Binnenflüchtlinge sowie zurückkehrender Flüchtlinge zu leisten. Darüber hinaus trägt das Projekt zur Stabilisierung der fragilen Sicherheitslage in den Projektstädten bei und fördert so die Friedenskonsolidierung vor Ort. Das stimmt mit den Forderungen im Marshallplan mit Afrika "Afrika und Europa - Neue Partnerschaft für Entwicklung, Frieden und Zukunft" überein. Der Ansatz zielt auf die Verbesserung sozialer und produktiver Infrastruktur und ist multisektoral, sodass Maßnahmen in den Bereichen Transport, Wasser- und Sanitärversorgung, Müllentsorgung, Bildung und Gesundheit möglich sind. In Mogadischu wurden bereits Maßnahmen im Bereich kommunale Infrastruktur identifiziert, für die Städte Kismayo, Baidoa und Garowe wurden Vorstudien erstellt. Die einzelnen Maßnahmen werden im Rahmen der Umsetzung festgelegt. Œ ŒZur Planung und Umsetzung der o.g. Maßnahmen werden die Strukturen des Multi Partner Fund der Weltbank (MPF) genutzt, der zur Umsetzung der FZ-Mittel ein gesondertes Finanzierungsfenster für städtische Infrastruktur einrichtet. Zur Förderung des von der Gebergemeinschaft angestrebten "State-Building" werden somalische Regierungsstrukturen soweit wie möglich in die Planung, Gestaltung und Umsetzung der Maßnahmen eingebunden. Auch die direkte Anbindung an den nationalen Entwicklungsplan ist damit sichergestellt.

title: Beschäftigungsbefähigung durch Stärkung beruflicher Qualifikation
description: Im Rahmen des Vorhabens soll der Zugang von Jugendlichen und jungen Menschen in drei ausgewählten Städten in den südlichen und zentralen Mitgliedsstaaten zu qualitativ hochwertiger Berufsbildung verbessert werden. Damit wird ein Beitrag zur Verringerung der Jugendarbeitslosigkeit und zur lokalen Wirtschaftsentwicklung geleistet. Hierfür werden schrittweise in Galkayo, Jowhar und Baidoa integrierte Gewerbeschulzentren aus- und neugebaut und ausgestattet. Das Konzept der integrierten Gewerbeschule zeichnet sich zum einen durch einen an klaren Qualitäts- und Prüfungskriterien ausgerichteten, praxisorientierten Unterricht aus. Zum anderen bieten die Gewerbeschulen verschiedene Dienstleistungen im Bereich Weiterbildung und Unternehmensförderung für die lokale Wirtschaft an. Das Vorhaben unterstützt die Gewerbeschulzentren dabei, ein breites Dienstleistungsangebot zu entwickeln, dadurch Einnahmen zu generieren und sich mit einem nachhaltigen Finanzierungsmechanismus langfristig selbst unterhalten zu können. Durch die Verankerung in die lokalen Gemeinden und den Einbezug benachteiligter und vulnerabler Jugendliche verschiedener Clans sowie von Binnenvertriebenen sollen die Gewerbeschulen als friedensstiftende Begegnungsorte und Entwicklungspole der lokalen Wirtschaft wirken.

title: Verbesserung des Katastrophenrisikomanagements und der Ernährungssicherung zur Stärkung der Resilienz in "Somaliland"
description: Die Voraussetzungen für eine gestärkte Resilienz der pastoralen und agro-pastoralen ländlichen Bevölkerung und Gemeinden sind verbessert.

title: Integriertes Programm zur Resilienzförderung in Somalia (FAO)
description: Kernproblem: ŒDie fragile Sicherheitssituation in Südwesten Somalia und die Häufung von extremen Naturereignissen hat die Lebensgrundlagen der Bevölkerung teilweise zerstört und ihre Vulnerabilität stark erhöht. Die schwachen staatlichen Institutionen sind dabei kaum in der Lage, diesen Herausforderungen effektiv zu begegnen. Œ ŒModulziel: ŒStärkung der sozioökonomischen Resilienz von Individuen, Haushalten und Gemeinden durch die Förderung ihrer Existenzgrundlagen, insbesondere der landwirtschaftlichen Produktion, sowie durch die Verbesserung des Zugangs zu angemessenen Basisdienstleistungen in den Bereichen Ernährung, Gesundheit, WASH und Bildung. Langfristig sollen der Zielgruppe damit bessere Bewältigungs- und Anpassungsmechanismen hinsichtlich ökonomischer und klimabedingter Schocks zur Verfügung stehen. Œ ŒWesentliche Outputs: ŒDas Programm wird gemeinschaftlich von UNICEF, WEP und FAO in der Region Gedo im Südwesten Somalias umgesetzt und umfasst folgende vier Komponenten: Œi) Schaffung der Voraussetzungen für ein sicheres und förderliches Lernumfeld und Bereitstellung von qualitativen Bildungsangeboten, insbesondere für benachteiligte Kinder und Jugendliche; Œii) Verbesserung des Zugangs zu grundlegenden Dienstleistungen in den Bereichen Ernährung, Wasser-, Sanitärversorgung und Hygiene (WASH), um die Widerstandsfähigkeit der Bevölkerung zu stärken; Œiii) Stärkung und Diversifizierung von Lebensgrundlagen über die nachhaltige Steigerung der agro-pastoralen Produktion und den Aufbau landwirtschaftlicher Wertschöpfungsketten; Œiv) Förderung lokaler Regierungs- und Verwaltungskapazitäten, um sie in die Lage zu versetzen, ihrer Bevölkerung eigenständig und nachhaltig angemessene Basisdienstleistungen anzubieten Œ ŒZielgruppe: ŒDie Zielgruppe sind bedürftige Haushalte, Kinder, schwangere und stillende Frauen sowie Binnenvertriebene in ausgewählten Distrikten der Region Gedo im Bundestaat Jubaland. Jährlich sollen ca. 146.000 Menschen von den Leistungspaketen profitieren. Œ ŒBeitrag zur nationalen Umsetzung der Agenda 2030: ŒDie somalische Regierung bekennt sich zu den Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) und hat ihren nationalen Entwicklungsplan auf diese abgestimmt. Das Vorhaben wird zu SDG 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 sowie SDG 15 beitragen.

title: Förderung der wirtschaftlichen und sozialen Teilhabe extrem armer RückkehrerInnen, Binnenvertriebener und der Bewohner
description: Promotion of economic and social inclusion of extremely poor IDPs and communities in Puntland, Somalia.

title: Risikomanagement
description: Die Voraussetzungen zur Minimierung von akuten und potenziellen Sicherheitsrisiken für GIZ Personal und Vorhaben sind verbessert.

title: Supporting Human Rights, Democracy and the Rules based International System in Somalia
description: Assistance in line with UK objectives on Supporting Human Rights, Democracy and the Rules based International System in Somalia which helps build prosperous and democratic countries, tackles the drivers of instability and insecurity, and addresses global challenges

title: WASH IN EMERGENCIES
description: By 2025, Children and their families access timely, sufficient and safe WASH services in humanitarian situations.

title: DEMAND GENERATION FOR HEALTHY OUTCOMES
description:
By 2025, parents, caregivers, children and pregnant women benefit from strengthened, evidence-informed communication approaches to
improve their health care practices.

title: SOCIAL NORMS
description:
By 2025, families and communities demonstrate strengthened capacity and commitment to protect children and women from violence,
exploitation and harmful practices.

title: CHILD POVERTY
description:
By 2025, the Federal and Member State governments are better able to deliver shock-responsive social protection programmes and
reach the most deprived.

title: WASH SERVICES IN COMMUNITIES
description: By 2025, more people in targeted rural and poor urban areas have access to sustainable and affordable safely managed WASH services

title: 5.3 CP IN EMERGENCIES
description:
Government welfare institutions and CSOs have the capacity to deliver protection services to children (boys and girls), including
during humanitarian situations.

title: 7.3 SOCIAL POLICY AND GENDER
description:
CRC, equity, gender-focused policies, strategies and government capacities are in place to identify socially and economically
excluded children and support increased access to basic social services

title: Supporting Pastoralism and Agriculture in Recent and Protracted Crises (SPARC)
description: The Supporting Pastoralism & Agriculture in Recurrent & Protracted Crises (SPARC) programme will help poor and vulnerable people better cope with crises and increase their resilience to recurring shocks and protracted crisis and conflict by addressing evidence gaps on the effectiveness of different programmes and policies supporting, rebuilding, and increasing the resilience of agricultural livelihoods. As a result of the programme more people will have access to quality agricultural support during protracted and recurrent crisis.

title: 1.2 HEALTH SYSTEMS STRENGTHENING
description:
The four health system component elements (Human resource, HMIS, Supply chain and logistics and health financing) for effective and
efficient delivery of services are in place and operational

title: WASH ENABLING ENVIRONMENT
description:
By 2025, Government authorities at federal and member state levels are better able to plan, coordinate and monitor the delivery of
adequate, equitable and affordable WASH services

title: MALNUTRITION PREVENTION
description:
Girls and boys under five years of age, adolescent girls and women during pregnancy and breastfeeding in Somalia have increased
and more equitable access to quality preventative nutrition services by 2025

title: 2.4 NUTRITION QUALITY
description:
Government and partners have enhanced capacity to deliver, monitor and report on services, strengthening the quality of nutrition
programmes.

title: CARE FOR CHILDREN WITH WASTING
description:
Girls and boys under five years of age in Somalia  have increased and more equitable access to quality nutrition services for early
detection and treatment of wasting by 2025

title: IMMUNIZATION
description: By 2025, Ministries of Health and implementing partners have strengthened capacity to deliver quality immunization services.

title: 3.1 WASH SAFE DRINKING WATER
description:
Increased number people, in rural areas, small towns and urban centres as well as at schools and health centres have access to safe
and affordable drinking water, especially women and girls.

title: 6.3 SOCIAL PROTECTION
description: New Element

title: CO Project Management Somalia
description:
The Work in Progress! Alliance is focused on unlocking the economic potential of young women and men in Egypt, Nigeria and Somalia.The project aims to enable them to generate sustainable and reasonable incomes  by finding regular employment or by them starting an enterprise.
The project has a holistic approach because a job alone does not guarantee a successful life in ones own country: 1)It is gender sensitive and inclusive: the programme aims to have 50% of the actively engaged youths be women. Forthe other 50% the programme focuses on the specific needs and participation of young men. 2) It focuses both on the supply and the demand in the labourmarket, and tries to link enterprises and job-seeking youths. 3) And it aims to change policies and develop an enabling environment: advocacy for enabling policies and having role models advocate for youth participation in decision making and at the labour market.
The most important goal of "Work in Progress!" is to improve the skills of young people and their economic prospects by creating jobs and stimulating entrepreneurship. The three major outcomes are as followed: 1) More young men and women have found paid jobs or are running their own enterprises. By improving their employability skills, improvetheir access to information, to exchange platforms to link them to business, accelerators and incubators, and financial investments. 2) Local SMEs see business grow resulting in newly created positions for youth. The project will improve the access to networks, knowledge and credit for Small and Medium Enterprises. 3) Policy measures adopted and implemented that are able to improve labor participation of youth (women in particular), and to promote a business environment. The project will involve influentialpeople in public and private sectors to take a lead in stimulating youth employment and business environment.

The project has a holistic approach because a job alone does not guarantee a successful life in ones own country: 1)It is gender sensitive and inclusive: the programme aims to have 50% of the actively engaged youths be women. Forthe other 50% the programme focuses on the specific needs and participation of young men. 2) It focuses both on the supply and the demand in the labourmarket, and tries to link enterprises and job-seeking youths. 3) And it aims to change policies and develop an enabling environment: advocacy for enabling policies and having role models advocate for youth participation in decision making and at the labour market.
The most important goal of "Work in Progress!" is to improve the skills of young people and their economic prospects by creating jobs and stimulating entrepreneurship. The three major outcomes are as followed: 1) More young men and women have found paid jobs or are running their own enterprises. By improving their employability skills, improvetheir access to information, to exchange platforms to link them to business, accelerators and incubators, and financial investments. 2) Local SMEs see business grow resulting in newly created positions for youth. The project will improve the access to networks, knowledge and credit for Small and Medium Enterprises. 3) Policy measures adopted and implemented that are able to improve labor participation of youth (women in particular), and to promote a business environment. The project will involve influentialpeople in public and private sectors to take a lead in stimulating youth employment and business environment.

title: CO-Drought Response in Somaliland
description:
The latest findings from a countrywide seasonal assessment conducted in December 2016 by the Famine Early Warning Systems Network indicate that over 2.9 million people face Crisis and Emergency (IPC Phases 3 and 4) across Somalia through June 2017. Somalia President Mohamed Abdullahi Farmajo declared the drought a national disaster on 28 February 2017.
Drought affected families are resorting to a range of negative coping strategies including reducing the number of meals eaten in a given day, skipping meals, accumulation of debts or obtaining food on credit from shops, as well as migration in search of livelihood. IDPs rely heavily on support from the host community. Besides, the maternal mortality rate for Somalia is among the highest in the world at 732 maternal deaths per 100,000 live births. Water shortage may also trigger further outbreak of water borne diseases.
Oxfam provides integrated EFSVL (Emergency Food Security and Vulnerable Livelihoods) and WASH (Water, Sanitation and Hygiene) support to vulnerable women, men, boys and girls affected by drought in Sool, Sanaag, Toghdeer and Awdal regions as an immediate life saving intervention whilst taking steps to ensure the response contributes to the capacity building and resilience of communities and partners. Gender and protection will be mainstreamed throughout the response. The key EFSVL interventions include the distribution of cash grants to households who have lost their livestock and financial support to the Ministry of Livestock for scale upof livestock mass vaccination, control of parasites, disease surveillance and treatment of clinical cases. The key WASH interventions include the protection and development of spring and shallow wells, provision of water supply through trucking and vouchers, construction of communal latrines, hygiene promotion activities and distribution of hygiene materials.

title: CO-Danyare Kalkaal (Support the Voiceles
description: Access to justice in Somaliland is a complex issue. Different justice systems work parallel to each other and the awareness of the population which route to justice to take is very low, particularly in rural areas. Government institutions and formal justice providers are primarily based in urban areas in Somaliland. Rural areas have therefore little to no access, making the informal system, Xeer, often the only one to deal with cases. This places women and youth in difficult situations as they do not form part of the elders group. Legal representation in the formal system is dire. Internally Displaced Peoples (IDPs) also face considerable challenges including but not limited to social, economic legal problems, shelter, inaccessibility to land, property, security, health and education. Therefore, with the proposed action this consortium seeks to contribute to increased access to fair and effective justice in Somaliland that adequately deals with community members# grievances, in particular those faced by women, youth, IDPs and minorities

title: CO-Somalia Twinning  Programme
description:
Over the past few years, #localising humanitarian aid# has been regularly raised as a necessity to fundamentally reform the humanitarian system to respond more effectively and equitably to today#s complex crises. The 2016 World Humanitarian Summit (WHS) brought together old and new voices for local humanitarian leadership, creating a space and momentum to speak out and bring change to the system, resulting in The Grand Bargain commitments to advance the localization agenda. In parallel, the Charter4Change, signed on to bymany INGOs, including Oxfam, further commits to reforming the humanitarian system to ensure greater influence and funding for localand national NGOs.

The Somalia NGO Consortium (SNC) and Oxfam Somalia are supporting this movement byplanning and implementing activities to more equitable shift and share power, knowledge, and resources between local, national and international humanitarian actors involved in Somalia#s humanitarian response, with a particular focus on supporting women#srights organisations (WROs) and addressing deeply embedded gender inequities. The SNC#s Strategy 2017-2019 includes as an outcome a #25 per cent of direct funding to Somalia Local NGOs and increased voice and representation with donors, United Nations (UN) and International NGO (INGO) by 2019#. Oxfam Somalia#s humanitarian influencing strategy 2018-2020 aims in its first objective at having more #effective and timely localised aid# to support drought and conflict affected populations. In the strategy, Oxfam Somalia aims to implement the localization agenda in a way that can help address Somalia women#s rights and gender justice and be a powerful agent of women#s transformative leadership in Somalia.

title: SOS Kinderdorpen-Somalia Joint Response
description: The Joint Response for Somalia is a project funded by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs through the Dutch Relief Alliance. Oxfam Novib is leading a consortium that consists of Dorcas, SOS Children#s Villages, World Vision and Oxfam Novib. The proposed projectaims to address the HRP objectives of providing life-saving and life-sustaining integrated, multi-sectoral assistance to reduce acute humanitarian need for communities affected by the drought and protracted conflict. The (revised) Humanitarian Response Plan, dated July 2018, states there are currently 5,4 mln people in need. The locations and sectors for project implementation are to be determined in a planning workshop taking place on 24 and 25 October, with representatives from the participating consortium members and local partners.

title: HO-Somalia Joint Response II
description: The Joint Response for Somalia is a project funded by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs through the Dutch Relief Alliance. In 2020, Oxfam Novib is leading a consortium that consists of Help a Child/ Medair, SOS Children#s Villages, World Vision and Oxfam Novib. The project aims to address the HRP objectives of providing life-saving and life-sustaining integrated, multi-sectoral assistanceto reduce acute humanitarian needs for communities affected by the drought and protracted conflict. The 2020 Joint Response has been designed in line with existing needs relevant to geography, sectors, as well as member#s expertise. Members will continue to implement in the same sectors as the SOMJR 2019: Food Security and Livelihoods, WASH, Health, Nutrition, Protection and Multi-Purpose Cash.

title: Somalia Joint Response II
description: The Somalia Joint Response is a project funded by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs through the Dutch Relief Alliance. The Consortium consists of four INGOs and six LNGOs and is led by Oxfam Novib. The four INGOs are: Oxfam Novib, Red een Kind, WorldVision and SOS Children#s Villages. The six LNGOs are: TASCO, Havoyoco, Candlelight, ZamZam, Dawa, KAALO. The Somalia Joint Response is present in Somaliland, Puntland and South Central (Mogadishu, Banadir). The proposed project aims to address the HRP objectives of providing life-saving and life-sustaining integrated, multi-sectoral assistance to reduce acute humanitarian need for communities affectedby the drought and protracted conflict. The Somalia Joint Response 2020 is a continuation of the response in 2019, and will focus on the following sectors: FSL, Protection, WASH, Health and Nutrition. A special focus will be on localisation and supporting LNGOs in capacity strengthening and becoming the lead of future responses. Improved accountability to affected populations will underpin the work of the response. The response will also subgrant the Somalia NGO Consortium for activities around localisation, risk management and coordination.

title: Mobile platform for employment creation
description:
The goal of the 12-monthproject is expanding opportunities for youth through innovative alternative financing for Startup#s and ignite new breed of entrepreneurs-and providing supporting service for entrepreneurs. the  aim is  to achieve this goal through three main objectives:
1. Support the creation of new breed of start-up, through alternative financing, acceleration and incubation.
2.ducate,  engage  and  connect  entrepreneurs  through  regular  meetups  and  educational experience sharing.
3. ntroduce alternative mid-size financing model, through the development of dedicated locally developed crowdfunding platformand matching-equity-basedfinancing for startups while attracting further funds fromfinancial institutions to scale up.
In total, thisproject is expected to ignite up to15Enterprisesandprovide them with access to financial and non-financial  services  that  build  or  expand  these  businesses  with  the  objective  ofcreating  an  additional 45 directjobs for youth. The start up huddlewill attract up to 720 attendees of which about 15will ignite or expand their business ideas after attending the Startuphuddlewhich will create additional 30 jobs bring thetotal 75 new employment opportunities.

title: CO-Somalia Resilience Program
description:
The program promotes bottom-up and top-down governance capacity development.  At HH and group level, the program will continue to expand the number of VSLAs, increasing the number of these social capital-developing and integration-promoting mechanisms.  Through the intensive GCVCA facilitated assessment process and subsequent development of CAAPs, SomReP will continue to place the community at the forefront of analyzing their own challenges and opportunities, and putting forth their own priorities and plans to help them better plan for and mitigate against shocks and promote food security and economic development.  The CAAP is the foundation for development planning at the community level, assisting community leadership to identify and prioritize development actions. Other organizations and consortia are also developing plans at community and district level; as such, SomReP will continue to jointly plan and coordinate actions at both Technical Unit and site level so as to ensure efficient use of multipledonors# resources in fulfillment of community needs.
In partnership with district and Member State line ministries, SomReP will undertake sector specific assessments targeting systems (e.g. water systems, market systems) which affect resilience buildingwithin and between villages.  During times of shock, SomReP will mobilize resources to partner with relevant line ministries to undertake assessment to support early response and post-shock recovery.  Village and village-cluster plans will be aggregated and support the development of district-level planning frameworks.  Through direct support to line ministries through secondments and other facilitative actions, the program will promote understanding of national and Member State Level frameworks (NDP andRRF) at the community planning level.  As Member State line ministries are supported to monitor uptake and progress towards achieving disaster risk management actions at community level, the government will both fulfill its mandate and begin to strengthen its ability to do this independently.

title: CO-Learning champions among Oxfam projec
description: This project will strengthen learning within Oxfam as well as from local partnerships. It#s hoped that entailing local partners, documenting and sharing learnings from Oxfam-Partner and Partner-Partner interactions will prioritize the southern agenda. The developed tools will become part of the overall MEAL tools and the info-graphs and short videos will ensure that knowledge is shared throughout Oxfam and with partners

title: CO-Enhancing Resilience in Somaliland
description:
This project is aimed to enhance community resilience in Berbera area, as part of  bigger SOMREP effort in promoting resilience across Somalia and somaliland.
This Project focus on community capacity development to withstand shocks and stresses with particular focus on drought hazard.
key pilers of the project includes VSLAs establishment at community level: development community action plan,enhance youth entrepreneurship   and support on marketable IGAs.  The project will support access to food security at household level through provision  of agricultural input  to potential farmers. A Total of 30,000 people are expected to benefit this project fora period of one year.

title: CO-integrated humanitarian Somalia respo
description:
About 4.6 million people in Somalia are food insecure and 4.2 million are in need of humanitarian assistance. The reduction in the number of people in need since early 2018 has been attributed to favourable rainfall during the Gu season (April to June) and sustained humanitarian assistance. Over 1.5 million people face acute food security Crisis or worse (IPC Phase 3 or higher) and approximately 3.1 million people are Stressed (IPC 2)1. Although the 2016/2017 drought has ended in most parts of Somalia, its adverse impact lingers among those who were impoverished or displaced, and pastoralists who lost all or most of their livestock, particularly in the north. Without sustained food and livelihood assistance, the latter are likely to remain in Emergency (IPC 4).
While acute malnutrition rates have improved nationally to Serious from Critical, the overall prevalence of acute malnutrition remains largely unchanged from Deyr 2017/2018. Between August and December, 294,000 acutely malnourished children, including 55,000 severe cases, aged underfive, will require treatment and integrated support. The acute malnutrition burden over the next 12 months is projected to be 588,400 acutely malnourished children, including 110,500 severe cases. The persistently high levels of acute malnutrition are unlikely toreduce without addressing the underlying causes, particularly in internally displaced persons (IDP) settlements and in some rural areas

title: Oxfam in Somalia Influencing Project
description:
In line with the OCS and Humanitarian Advocacy Strategy, Oxfam#s standalone influencing activities will center on the following thematic areas:
1. Women#s Empowerment: addressing the deep and widespread gender gap, particularly foregrounding the influence of women#s rights organisations.
2. Localisation of Aid: agitating for change related to the persistent barriers towards localisation of aid in both humanitarian and development fields, in close alliance with local and national partners.
3. Debt Relief: in collaboration with the Debt Working Group, seeking expedited, full debt cancellation for Somalia at the highest levels.
4. Youth Empowerment: addressing the specific needs, challenges and aspiration of youth, particularly in terms of influence in decision-making, education and employment.
5. Protection: leveraging our humanitarian presence to identify key protection issues and influence for change, while also feeding into broader protection work, such as with the Regional Durable Solutions Secretariat.

title: CO-Contribution To Humanitarian Response
description:
Based on the assessed humanitarian needs and projections for 2019, the response strategy remains focused on a two-pronged approach:

1.) To provide urgent life-saving, life-sustaining and dignity upholding assistance in response to food insecurity, water shortage, disease outbreak and protection risks that are faced as a result of recurrent drought.
2.) Investing in resilience and recovery interventions to work with communities, government institutions and other key stakeholders towards a more sustainable solution to the cyclical disasters in Somalia.

Overall Goal: To meet the immediate life-saving needs of 500,000 drought affected people and providesustainable solutions to improve the coping capacity of vulnerable communities to the effects of drought.

It must be stressed thatcross-cutting the entire humanitarian strategy is a commitment to localisation, safe programming working closely alongside local partners, line ministries and communities in implementing the response and recovery interventions, building capacity and longer-term sustainability along the way.

title: Support of NEXUS Consortium in Somalia
description:
Nexus is launching an Institutional Development Unit to invest strategically in the growth of its members, research critical areas to develop action-oriented agendas for thought leadership and advocacy, and advance partnerships with Somali government entities andthe private sector. This project will kickstart these initial Nexus interventions in three areas that together will provide a critical foundation for Nexus# thought leadership and civil society strengthening efforts in years to come, particularly in relation to gender justice:
1. Delivery of a 6-month gender leadership program to support gender champions inside and outside its platform, both civil society and government.
2. Research into women#s leadership in humanitarian
response in Somalia and Somaliland to be leveragedfor advancing women#s leadership.
3. Establishment of the Institutional Development Unit, including development of common criteria and institutional development plans.

title: CO-Emergency response in Somalia
description: The project will ensure access to clean portable water with water-point rehabilitation and Cash for Water initiative in times of crisis (e.g. dry season or failed rains); improved sanitation through construction of HH shared latrines and provision of latrine cleaning kits; and improved hygiene practices with hygiene promotion and key inputs (particularly targeting the menstrual hygiene needs of women and girls of reproductive age). The Food Security and Livelihoods component of the project will deliver Multi-Purpose Cash to assist vulnerable households to access food and other necessities. Oxfam will collaborate with the Ministry of Livestock in a livestock vaccination campaign to treat the most common endo and ecto parasites to improve animal health in pastoralist communities, and will further work with vulnerable youth and women to diversify their livelihoods with vocational skills training and piloting of Voluntary Savings Groups. This will help increase employability and income, and will also contribute to building the capacity of women to take a more active role in decision making in their communities. The project will incorporate specific community protection activities engaging community protection volunteers, existing community committees and women#s groups to raise and mitigate protection risks at community level. Oxfam will map available services in target communities and engage with service providers on confidential referral pathways. Trainings on basic protection principles, rights and responsibilities will target community committees, women#s groups, community protection volunteers and relevant authorities will be capacity built to strengthen regional and national protection mechanisms.

title: CO-Somali-land Emergency Response  Proje
description:
To ensure and address the immediate food needs of target communities in Sool and Sanaag who are facing food insecurity levels of IPC 4, 3.500 HHs (21:000 individuals: 12.390 female, 8.610 male), they will receive multi purpose cash transfer for a period of three months, mitigating the impact of the drought throughout the lean season.
The livelihood component of this intervention will protect both household and community assets through the protection of core breeding animal by provision of fodder to vaccinated animals, targeting 90.000 head of livestock, benefiting 9.000 HHs (54.000 individuals; 31.860 female and 22.140 male). Training and provision ofveterinary start-up kits for 40 Community Animal Health Workers will benefit 3.600 households for treatment of their livestock.
In the WASH component of the action these communities directly benefit from a comprehensive package of immediate access to safe water, sanitation facilities and improved hygiene practices, including Cash for Water for 3 months for 1.760 of the most vulnerable households, improved storage capacity by provision of 16 communal water tanks, 2 jerry cans per household, and 420 emergency latrines for 4.167 HH (25.002 people), improved access to water by provision of fuel for 5 strategic borehole generators for 3 months, and maintenance of the boreholes will benefit 25.000 individuals (4.167 HH). To promote a safe water chain, Oxfam will distribute water treatment tablets for 3 months to cash for water recipients through hygiene promotion activities, for point of use household water treatment, with a focus on community engagement and participation. This will be accompanied by promotion of the adoption of good hygiene practices. Oxfam will also focus on community engagement initiatives including action planning, periodic review meetings on progress and programme processes, as well to obtain community feedback on the implementation modalities. Community volunteers will be trained on safe water chain, transmission route of water and sanitation related diseases, and preparation of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to promote adoption of good hygiene practices and manage dehydration amongst communities.
All this will be further supported throughprotection interventions. An ongoing protectionanalysis will ensure that activities can adapt to changes in the protection situation, that protection trend information can be shared with appropriate stakeholders, and that advocacy can be carried out where appropriate and necessary. Information on protection and existing services will be disseminated to women and men in target communities so that they are able to make informed decisions when faced with a protection threat or issue. WaSH and EFSL community committees and volunteers will be trained on protection risk analysis, and on how to receive and transmit protection information responsibly. A totalof 3.500 households will benefit from better information and a improved programming as a result.'

title: CO-Somalia Drought Response (Marisla)
description:
Somalia has experienced recurrent droughts since 2011 which have been increasingly exacerbated by climate change. Agro-pastoralistsand pastoralists have been badly affected by the 2019 drought which has caused widespread crop failure, water shortages, and depleted livestock levels.
More than 4.2 million people were estimated to be in need of humanitarian assistance in 2019, and the number ofpeople who are food insecure is expected to increase in the coming months.  This year#s severe drought has been caused by abnormally hot, dry conditions during January-March and the failure of the rains in April-June. Most households are already adopting negativecoping strategies to mitigate food insecurity, including reducing food intake. Poor transportation and market infrastructure make it difficult for pastoralists to access markets, and there are few fed markets to provide animals with nutrition when natural pastures are inadequate. Over 80% of livestock was lost as a result of the 2017 drought, and the population of livestock herds, essential for pastoralists# food and income, have not yet recovered.
The impact of the 2019 drought on the water and sanitation sector has beensignificant. Water supply (boreholes, shallow wells) is severely limited and the cost of accessing water has increased sharply, representing a severe burden on insufficient household income. Existing groundwater sources contain a highly mineralized content, rendering it unsuitable for drinking, but a prior Oxfam needs assessment showed that the vast majority of households in the project area do not treat their water. Open defecation remains common, increasing protection risks for women and girls who venture outside alone or during the night or move far from dwellings to known open defecation areas.
Oxfam aims to assist at least 500,000 affected peoplewith immediate food security and WASH programming along with resilience and recovery interventions to diminish the impact of recurring droughts on vulnerable populations. Oxfam will embed activities to strengthen the protection of women, men, boys, and girls within the EFSVL and WASH workstreams.

title: CO-DRA POC Development Process Somalia
description:
Core Humanitarian Standard, evidence-based and that meets needs holistically by integrating a triple nexus approach. This model will be peer-reviewed by other experts in the Global South. Once further funding is secured, it will become operational, with multiple organizations making varied, layered contributions to common outcomes according to their strengths # to ensure humanitarian responses uphold interwoven development and peace objectives and are thereby sustainable and transformative.
Additionally, the platform willproduce a robust operating procedure for its Anticipatory Response Fund, which serves as an emergency response mechanism/crisis modifier. Many INGOs, including Oxfam in Myanmar and Bangladesh, have successfully piloted this response mechanism with local partners.Upon request by local partners, the Somalia Joint Response is also piloting this mechanism with local partners in 2020, and all SOMJR INGOs have included a crisis modifier in their budgets in 2020. The Anticipatory Response Fund serves as a means for local humanitarian partners to quickly access funding to respond to sudden crises and emergencies. The fund's aim is to address funding gaps andensure quick access to emergency funding for local responders. The fund will build oncurrent initiatives in country to promote local humanitarian leadership and preparedness, and deliver on commitments made in the Grand Bargain and Charter for Change by donor andNGO signatories. It will also identify strengths and areas for capacity development in relation to emergency response in Somalia The operating procedure for the Anticipatory Response Fund will include triggers and related protocols, such that a pilot test of triggers, collaboration mechanisms and protocols can take place ahead ofthe humanitarian response windows, in the second half of 2020.
Beyond the pilot phase, these actions will lay the foundations for a response mechanism that is pre-emptive and therefore efficient and highly responsive # improving the quality of locally-led humanitarian response in Somalia and Somaliland. Delivering on the ambition statement (i.e. development of above-mentioned model for humanitarian programming and operating procedures) will contribute to all four DRA strategic priorities: 1) more effective support for locally-led responses by supporting Nexus as locally-led platform; 2) innovation and learning by generating knowledge outputs and new ways of working; 3) collaboration for increased effectiveness by bringing together a wide range of localactors with coverage of all 9 regions of Somalia and Somaliland; and 4) more accountable humanitarian action by giving voice and decision making power to local organisations and adding rigor through South-South peer review.

title: CO-Swiss Development Project in Somalila
description:
The project contributes to resilience  building in somaliland, as part of SOMREP effort to addressing the root causes of volubilities.
This project will build  the capacity of people to adopt  climate related Hazards through livelihood diversification, skills development, income generation and community based capacity building,the project will be implemented in Ceel-Afwayn and will be a threeyear period project.
The project is expected to build the resilience  of the community to withstand recurrent  droughts taking place in the area. the nature  of activities  will build on the on going humanitarian responses and act as Nexus between humanitarian and development.

title: CO-50
description: Oxfam in Somalia aims to compare available Google Trends data for Somalia, and Somaliland specifically, with data from existing research and MEAL systems from Oxfam in Somalia and local partners. We will determine if Google Trends data can be used to monitor changes in social norms around women/youth political participation.

title: HO-503001
description: Oxfam in Somalia aims to compare available Google Trends data for Somalia, and Somaliland specifically, with data from existing research and MEAL systems from Oxfam in Somalia and local partners. We will determine if Google Trends data can be used to monitor changes in social norms around women/youth political participation.

title: Shuraako  SMEs Competition
description:
We will select 3 companies to enter into a dedicated scale-up trajectory; 1 company per country. The pilot will be running in Somalia, Egypt, and Uganda. The goal of the trajectory is to professionalize their (international) growth strategy and where possible to help find (international) partners, in supply, trade or investment.

Objectives
The primary objective of the competition is to accelerate societal (innovative) impact through SMEs and start-ups <(>&<)> job opportunities for youth. The secondary objective of this pilot is to get the best examples of impact-driven SMEs in our countries and understand what it takes for them to scale-up, both their business and impact. This will allow us to improve our programme further by including working with superstar impact SMEs into our approach. Thirdly, we can use these #superstars# as best examples of the kind of companies we want to support, so to use it in our communication towards donors, investors, other Oxfam countries and other stakeholders.

title: CO-Somaliland -Work in Progress!! II
description:
Our strategy combines service delivery, such as trainings, with influencing interventions to change policies, laws, attitudes and beliefs. This has proved successful in the last three years. The strategy engages young women and men from diverse backgrounds to be a driving force for social progress and optimism about the future in their respective countries and across Africa.

When we worked with stakeholders in each country to analyse the current situation faced by young men and women, we found three common key needs:
1. Improving curricula and training methods, creating new modules and connecting the curricula to the demands of the market.
2. Innovation to respond to social issues such as climate change, gender rights and urbanization.
3. Linking service delivery interventions with influencing interventions # young people do not need only better training and new skills, but also changes to the system: policies, laws, practices and the attitudes and beliefs of their fellow citizens, employers and the government.
These conclusions have guided this proposal in further developing interventions and adapting activities for each country for 2020-2022. We will highlight new interventions in the following chapters.

Our strategy is based on systems thinking: trying to understand how different parts of a system interact to effect change, rather than understanding specific components in isolation. Systems thinking can help to develop truly sustainable and transformative change. The below graphic illustrates the #system# for youth seeking employment in Somaliland, mapping the relationships of actors including education institutions, hubs, teachers, government, banks, entrepreneurs, families and media.

These conclusions have guided this proposal in further developing interventions and adapting activities for each country for 2020-2022. We will highlight new interventions in the following chapters.
Our strategy is based on systems thinking:trying to understand how different parts of a system interact to effect change, rather than understanding specific components in isolation. Systems thinking can help to develop truly sustainable and transformative change. The below graphic illustrates the#system# for youth seeking employment in Somaliland, mappingthe relationships of actors including education institutions, hubs, teachers, government, banks, entrepreneurs, families and media.

title: Somaliland -Work in Progress!! II
description:
Our strategy combines service delivery, such as trainings, with influencing interventions to change policies, laws, attitudes and beliefs. This has proved successful in the last three years. The strategy engages young women and men from diverse backgrounds to be a driving force for social progress and optimism about the future in their respective countries and across Africa.
When we worked with stakeholders in each country to analyse the current situation faced by young men and women, we found three common key needs:
1. Improving curricula and training methods, creating new modules and connecting the curricula to the demands of the market.
2. Innovation to respond to social issues such as climate change, gender rights and urbanization.
3. Linking service delivery interventions with influencing interventions # young people do not need only better training and new skills, but also changes to the system: policies, laws, practices and the attitudes and beliefs of their fellow citizens, employers and the government.
These conclusions have guided this proposal in further developing interventions and adapting activities for each country for 2020-2022. We will highlight new interventions in the following chapters.
Our strategy is based on systems thinking:trying to understand how different parts of a system interact to effect change, rather than understanding specific components in isolation. Systems thinking can help to develop truly sustainable and transformative change. The below graphic illustrates the#system# for youth seeking employment in Somaliland, mappingthe relationships of actors including education institutions, hubs, teachers, government, banks, entrepreneurs, families and media.

title: Somaliland -Work in Progress!! III
description:
WiP!’s theory of change identifies three key pathways – which inform our aims – to enable young people from diverse backgrounds to generate sustainable living wages and create optimism about their future in Egypt, Nigeria and Somalia. Two pathways are geared towards service delivery through competence development, while the third is about influencing.
Pathway 1:
We build young people’s skillsfor today and the future to find paid jobs or set up their own enterprises.
WiP! will continue to provide new cohorts of young people with 21st century and technical skills. In a rapidly changing labour market, this will better prepare them to find a job and givethem the confidence to plan their future. Collaboration with educational institutions will be strengthened to ensure scale-up and
sustainability by integrating 21st century skills, Futures Literacy1 and other training modules developed during WiP! into their curricula, and by promoting internships. Additionally, youth will be trained in the skills, tools and mindset of design thinking to solve complex social issues.
After training, job fairs will be organized to link the students with employers. Providing service deliverythrough skills building goes
hand in hand with influencing government and employers to promote and provide decent jobs for young people.
We assume that 21st century skills such as Futures Literacy and design thinking will prepare young women and men for the future job market. We also assume that teachers and trainers are convinced these skills are needed to
prepare for the future job market, and that there are enough employers to absorb trained young people.
Pathway 2:
Not all young people are looking for a job – many want to be entrepreneurs. We accelerate startups and offer business development services (BDS) to impact-driven small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) so they can employ more young people – improving the demand side of the market – and deepen their social and environmental impact. We aim to improve networks, knowledge, skills and access to finance and investors for new entrepreneurs and established SMEs while further activating and training private sector professionals as
coaches and mentors. To contribute to a greener economy, we started focusing even more on sustainable entrepreneurship and integrating the training on circular business models which we started in 2019.
We assume in this pathway that young people (men and women) are recruited once SMEs and startups grow. We assume investors are interested to invest in early startups and in the trained SMEs. And we assume that SMEs are open to adapting their business models with elements of the circular economy to contribute to a greener future.
Pathway 3
WiP! aims to improve the enabling environment for youthand enterprises. Building on the relationships established in the first three and a half years, we will
engage with different actors (governments, private sector and young citizens) to improve the implementation of policies on decent jobs and supportingstartups and SMEs.
Working with role models, we will have youth- led public campaigning to raise awareness about obstacles they face. We will especially emphasize issues women entrepreneurs
face because of their gender. We will aim in particular to improvethe internship policy in Somalia to bridge the gap between study and work, and policies of banks and workplaces in Nigeria to improve SMEs’ access to loans and create more decent jobs for young people.
For pathway 3 we assume that we can change attitudes and beliefs in a short period of four years. We assume that educational institutes will be able to adapt their curricula to include the 21stcentury skills trainings. We assume government officials are willing to implement the policies we advise andwork with them
to develop. And we assume that cultural and social norms and practices on gender roles can evolve to encourage more women to become entrepreneurs.

title: Citizenship Project
description:
The Ministry of Parliamentary Relations and Constitutional Affairs #MoPCA# has been conducting awareness programs aimed at educating citizens about their constitutional rights and their obligations. Thus far, MoPCA has implemented an awareness programs, which arenow broadcast on Radio and TV. The radio program has a wide coverage of people as it reaches almost all over the country. Furthermore, MoPCA has signed agreement with the Ministry of Education and Science as regards incorporating civic educationcourses into the curriculum of high primary schools, secondary schools and universities. The curriculum for the three preceding streams has been finalized recently and the teaching of the civic education is expected to begin soon.
In addition, MoPCA intends to train all government institutions to ensure that such institutions respect the constitutional rights of the citizens. The essence of the training of the government institutions on the constitutional rights is to enhance the protection of basic human rights and to strengthen the rule of law. So far, MoPCA has trained the Good Governance and Anti Corruption Commission as well as 1000 young men who were undertaking their National Service training at Dararweyne training school. The ministry also visited regional universities to train National Service girls who were attached to different universities to complete their national service requirements. MoPCA will continue training other government institutions on constitutional rights of the citizens.
Similarly, the Ministry has also distributed large quantities of the copies of the constitution as well as brochures and pamphlets aimed at raising citizens# awareness vis-à-vis their constitutional rights and their obligations as well. The ministry is also planning to visit regions and hold town-hall meetings with different citizens residing in regions. The aim of these town-hall meetings is to disseminate the constitution and to gather data as regards the views and opinions of society with respect to theirknowledge about their constitutional rights. MoPCA will also undertake consultative meetings in all regions.

title: CO-Enhancing Resilience in Somaliland II
description:
Specific objective/ Outcome:  Sustainably improve food security and livelihoods of Somali people, households, communities through effective risk management, protection of productive assets, improved governance of resilience structures, and promotion of innovations and evidence based programming.
Intermediary Outcome 1: Improved capacity of households to implement disaster risk management and positive coping strategies to mitigate the immediate effect of exposure to shock.
Intermediary Outcome 2: Improved capacity of individuals, households and communities to adhere to positive development trajectories; despite exposures to shocks and utilize strategies designed to allow adaptation to rapid and slow on-set hazards.
Intermediary Outcome 3: Improved capacity to engage in strategies for sustainable livelihoods and economic growth to enhance food security and resilience

title: CO-Somalia Desert Locust Response Projec
description:
Specific objective:  To curb the spread of Desert Locust, pprotect and recover Livelihoods of the people affected by Locust disaster in Somaliland and Puntland.
Result 1: Improved locust control mechanisms and capacitate/enable government and local community to minimize negative effects on livelihoods of people affected by desert locust.
Result 2: Reduced impact of desert locust and support early livelihood recovery through provision critical agriculture inputs and livestock fodder.
Activities
1.1. Support 10 community mobilization campaigns and trainings at ground level, on locust control.
1.2. 600 people undertake mechanical control (digging trenches and driving hopper bands into them) through cash for work
1.3. 3 community awareness campaigns through media outlets, reaching 24 villages with an average population of 350 HHs each (8500HHs to be reached through awareness and outreach on locust).
1.4        Conduct one baseline, and one Post Distribution Monitoring.

title: Increasing  Agricultural Production
description:
Oxfam has rehabilitated dozens of boreholes in Sool and Sanaag region, most of those water structure has solar system in place. Oxfam#s assessment found pout that some of those structures are not used by people due to varying reasons. Oxfam EFSVL and WASH team discussed this issue and propose we combine water and agricultural production. Oxfam will support ministry of agriculture to assess 6-7 water points in those two regions aimed to start agricultural production. The government will mobilize communities and familiarizethem agricultural production. It is expected that linking existing water sites to agriculture will improve nutritional. Mionistry of agriculture will enhane agricultural practices by introducing agriculture around those water points. The ministry will provide seeds, knowledge regularly using its field staff.
Nutrition-Sensitive Agriculture is good-based approach to agricultural development that puts nutritionally rich foods, dietary diversity and food fortification at the heart of overcoming malnutrition and micronutrientdeficiencies. This assignment focuses on the utilization of water resource for agriculture sector to improve the nutritional value of foods for good nutrition, health and productivity, and social significance of farming and supporting rural livelihood specially that pregnant, lactating women and child.
# The main objective of this mission is to investigate the suitability of borehole water resource for utilization for irrigation purpose.
# Understanding Perception of the community for benefiting water for agriculture purpose
# The MOAD consultants will observe the appropriateness of nature of land (soil type, topography, soil nutrient) for crop production and predict the method of irrigation that could be used.
# During the field exercise, the consultants will analyze the proper ways of community water allocation for domestic use, animal watering and irrigation.
# The consultants will investigate the current situation of agricultural production status and level of nutrition of beneficiaries# community.
# Consultants will have soil and water samples

title: CO-Desert Locust Crisis Response
description:
Specific objective:  To curb the spread of Desert Locust, pprotect and recover Livelihoods of the people affected by Locust disaster in Somaliland and Puntland.
Result 1: Improved locust control mechanisms and capacitate/enable government and local community to minimize negative effects on livelihoods of people affected by desert locust.
Result 2: Reduced impact of desert locust and support early livelihood recovery through provision critical agriculture inputs and livestock fodder

title: CO-Somalia Locust Control Measures
description:
Oxfam has been working in Somalia for over 40 years, working with Somali people and organisations implementing humanitarian, resilience and development programmes. Humanitarian response focuses on WaSH, EVFSL and Protection.
Oxfam has made a lot of gains through humanitarian resilience programmes which are likely to be eroded if the desert locust menace is uncontrolled. Oxfam will therefore capitalise and work with the existing community structures such as Early Warning Committees, Government line ministries, FAO and other stakeholders on the preventive and control measures.
Oxfam will prioritize safeguarding livelihoods focusing on cash intervention and locust control measures.

A total of 1,056 people in coastal areas of Sool region will be reachedby the project and supported toprotect and recover their livelihoods.

Oxfam has vast experience in implementing conditional and unconditional cash transfer approaches in WASH, EVFSL programmes. The project will specifically focus on the Cash for Work(CfW) approach as it not only empowers individuals to spend based on their priority needs but also focuses on revamping community assets. CfW will therefore stimulate the recovery of the local economy by creating short-term work, reintroduce income flow,supporting local businesses through the purchase worktools while also encouraging households to purchase food and non-food items locally. The trench digging will involve large numbers of the population and will be designed to encourage the integration and participation of women and other marginalized groups in an area thus benefitting the entire community and not just a few individuals.

The project will support communities to address locust spread by burying them in trenches excavated through cash for work. A total of 1,056 people will dig 26 km of trenches and drive hopper bands through cash for work, this task will continue for 30 days, 15 days per month starting in mid-March 2020. This task is expected to minimize hopper bands probability to turn to dangerous swarm level while at the same time communities will be able to access cash to help them address food insecurity situation at household level.

Oxfam will closely cooperate with the Somaliland Ministry of agriculture

title: CO-COVID-19 Help Line
description:
a. Receive and make calls to the application through existing three-digit toll free short code.
b. Manages region-based calls and direct to appropriate call centers in the six Somaliland regions.
c. Customize existing application to handle multiple calls at the same time.
d. Provide an option for callers to access up to date information on the virus based on the Ministry of Health and WHO guidelines through toll free number (Telesom will cover Short code and calling minutes).
e. Provide Symptoms screening checker to all callers to answer few questions over the phone to determine whether they at risk and provide appropriate advice.
f.  Speak to caller center operator for further information and support.
2. Assisting capacitate the existing call center in Hargeisa and establish additional 5 call centers with three health workers manning each call center.
3. Train the call center staff to manage the help line platform, receive calls, process audio messages and call back people who could not get through. Provide regular reports to committee and potential high risks cases for action when the times comes.
4. Maintain and support the platform for the duration of the pandemic.
5. The ministry would also create group of their health works system to send out rapid messages.

The key feature of the service isthe ability to handle multiple calls, leave voice messages if the caller can#t get through, symptoms screening and provision of up to date information as per the Ministry of Health and WHO guidelines.
A total of 18 call center staff volunteers from the Ministry of Health will be trained through a two days workshop in Hargeisa to train them on the platform and dealing with callers during this difficult time. Three call center volunteers will be selected from each of the six main regions in Somaliland including Marodijeex, Awdal, Saxil, Todgheer, Sool and Sanaag. Volunteers will through shifts and lines will be closed from 5pm each day and opens at 7am.During this time, system will direct all callers to voice mail system. It is expected that there will be large number of spam messages and the platform will be designed to handle spam callers.

Volunteers will through shifts and lines will be closed from 5pm each day and opens at 7am.During this time, system will direct all callers to voice mail system. It is expected that there will be large number of spam messages and the platform will be designed to handle spam callers.

title: CO-Desert Locust - Joint Response
description: The Desert Locust Joint Response is a 6 month emergency response project focusing on FSL and Cash interventions to control the spread of locust and support communities (agropastoralists and pastoralists) in coping with the loss of livelihoods due to locust invasions. All activities will be accompanied by COVID-19 WASH preparedness interventions, focusing on Public Health Promotion and the distribution of hygiene items. SOS Somaliland is the lead for this Joint Response (DRA). Oxfam will deliver the project with partners Candlelight and KAALO, who will work in Eastern Somaliland and Puntland (Togdheer, Sool, Nugal). Oxfam will respond in Awdal and Togdheer.

title: CO-COVID-19 Pandemic Support
description:
Description of the crisis (including number of affected, timeline, number of affected Oxfam has reached to date etc):
COVID-19 (Coronavirus acute respiratory disease) was first identified in late 2019 in Wuhan in Hubei province, China, and has since spread globally, resulting in the ongoing pandemic. While there are so far only seven laboratory-confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Somalia (first case: 16 March 2020), it must be noted there are no testing facilities and tests are currently sent to South Africa. Results are received after two weeks. The country has only 15 intensive care unit beds and ranks 194th out of 195 in the Global Health Security Index. Over a third of Somalis do not have enough clean, safe water to meet their daily needs, let alone for more frequent preventive handwashing. It goes without saying that an outbreak of COVID-19 in Somalia would have a devastating impact on vulnerable communities who already suffer from drought, conflict and most recently, locust invasion. 6.3 million Somalis are food insecure, 2.1 million internally displaced. The below activities would provide Oxfam Somalia and our partners with a top-up to the 50,000 GBP recently received through the CAT Fund.
Project description / activities (including numbers to be reached):
An additional 100,000 GBP (50% as loan, 50% as grant) will enable Oxfam and our partners to scale up the WASH preparedness activities as well as support partner Shaqodoon on extending the COVID-19 helpline to Somalia#s Puntland State. Shaqodoon are currently in the process of completing the set-up of the helpline in Somaliland (with support from the current CAT Fund grant); to be launched by 11th April. The helpline in Puntland willfollow the same process as in Somaliland: Shaqodoon will develop the system and link it to a toll-free Coronavirus hotline providedby Puntland#s Ministry of Health. The Ministry of Health will work closely with WHO and identify health personnel who will be trained in receiving and processing calls. Shaqodoon will provide pre-recorded health messages, on-site technical support and data analysis/dashboards for the Ministry.

The remaining amount will be utilised to scale up COVID-19 preparedness activities in Somaliland and Puntland, in collaboration with partners. Itwill also be used to top-up partners# crisis modifiers from other donors to make theircontribution in this fight, more meaningful. Activities include set-up of handwashing points in settlements, purchase and distribution of hygiene kits to IDP communities, dispatching mobile teams to disinfect busy public areas and purchase of HTH chlorine pumps for disinfection.

50,000 people will be reached by Oxfam#s and partners# WASH COVID-19 preparedness activities.
Shaqodoon through the Ministry of Health of Puntland hopes to reach a majority of Puntland#s phone users with COVID-19 information sharing and prevention messaging.

title: CO-Covid-19 Protection Intervention
description:
As part of COVID19 preparedness and response  Oxfam and Shaqodoon local partner in collaboration with ministry of health and Telesom company have jointly set up and launched an interactive COVID-19 call center in Hargeisa. The call center plays a vital role in the dissemination of up-to-date and accurate and reliable information to the public, it provides prerecorded prevention guidelines; audio-based symptoms pre-screening options; counseling and medical assistance from health professionals and referrals to the emergencyand quarantine centers nearby. The center also feeds the government a way of tracking suspect cases information for emergency action and is alternative mechanism  for those have not physical access to government health facilities related to COVID. The call centerhas a toll free 24/7 available short code number (988) accessible from all over the country with 14 dedicated call agents who handle and process calls and voice messages, 2 professional doctors available for the management of suspect cases who provide counseling on daily bases to the callers and 2 technical assistance.
The call center receives 294,427 calls since its inception. Shaqodoon sends daily reports of the center including information of the suspect cases to the ministry of health to inform their daily plans regarding COVID19.
some of the Major project activities are :
- Supporting your partners in adapting to Covid-19 situation so that they can continue to provide protection services
- Adapting referrals to the newsituation # remotely?
- Supporting Protection committees to adapt their activities/ prepare for activities during lockdown (e.g. material needed, technical advice)
- Preparing to stay in touch with communities if movement restrictions get stricter (e.g.communication systems needed)
- Remote protection monitoring
